headline: Great place to start your career.
pros:
25 Days Vacation
The relationship with upper management is really good.  You get feedback on a regular basis from many different  managers at different levels.  
The firm has an emphasis on work life balance.  They allow you to be flexible with work schedules as long as you still get your work finished. 
KPMG encourages and allows for rotations to different places around the world.  
KPMG also has many short term travel opportunities that you can encounter when working at all levels of the organization.
cons:
Longer work weeks than you will find in "industry", but the same as other big 4.
Sometimes you can look back and find that your month was crazy traveling all over the place, but it does not seem bad if you are ok with a changing environment.

headline: Not a place where innovative minds can sustain
pros:
* Good brand name
* The best in their business
* Contribute a lot to the community, always help the employees when they need assistance
cons:
* Work is highly task oriented and measured on hourly basis, some managers even question a 15 mins coffee break
* Highly captive mode of setup, the managers in USA want reason, from the Indian colleagues, for anything and everything including your personal reasons why you cant attend a late meeting... 
* ...and yes meetings are mandatory and in most of the teams they run till midnight. US managers expect even female colleagues stay on calls till or beyond midnights.
* The offshore colleagues are treated like vendors and trust level is even lower than that's on vendors.
* Pretty bad work culture and power games everywhere.
* HR always finds an excuse not to offer a competitive salary in the market
* Annual Bonus is paid 3 months after the financial/compensation year end and as long as you are not serving notice - that means you lose 5 months of bonus whenever you leave the company
* Lot of regional politics if you are working out of the India office, language/regional based biasing and preferences, people who questions are rated lower etc.

headline: Great place
pros:
Benefits to KPMG: 1: Generally great people who care and willingly try to take into account work life balance. 2: Interesting work with responsibility and generally a culture of understanding when there is no work then no need to pretend/act like you are working. 3: Good location with modern office. 4: Free lunch allowance of £3.20. 5: Qualification paid for and desire by everyone to provide support and advice. 6: Flexible outlook on career progression with desire to facilitate interests and passions.

KPMG is a great place to work and would recommend to everyone.
cons: The cons to KPMG are significantly outweighed by the pros but here they are. 1: There are some people in more senior roles who lack social skills and make you wonder how they are where they are but these are 1 out of 200. 2: Office lacks positive communal spaces which facilitates networking across the firm. There was a games room which was removed without consultation. 3: The canteen is expensive and the £3.20 allowance does not provide many options.

headline: Great place to jumpstart your global career.
pros: KPMG is a great place to develope your skills and build your career. They have a lot of training vehicles available and promote heavily on globalization. Both short-term and long-term international rotation programs are available to the right candidate. My coworkers are great and we are all very respectful of one another, KPMG encourages teamwork and does a great job in creating this kind of environment.
cons: Compensation does not reflect very well when compared to the number of hours worked per dollar. Also, the international rotation programs might be very difficult to get into if your service line of business is limited nationally.

headline: Great place to build business skills, less so for advanced technical skills
pros: Prestigious work at a name-brand firm that can build your resume and accelerate your career. The travel is fun for awhile if you get on projects in good cities, too.
cons:
- Constant travel
- Little technical training and guidance. The firm doesn't really know what to do with advanced tech people just yet. This place is all about soft-skills and business
- Some projects are boring or not challenging, and you may find yourself surprisingly bored for all the talk people do about being super busy

headline: It is all politics!
pros:
- good work/life balance (but I came from a banking background where I had to work much harder)
- good benefits
-  interesting work (when you can get it)
cons:
- the politics, nothing gets done without the approval of about 5 different partners, all with different views and big egos
- analysis by paralysis culture
- completely disregard for its staff, I was surprised about this when I joined as KPMG had Won the Sunday Times best company to work for. It is all about which partner likes you and promotions, internal roles are based on that as opposed to merit
- some silly decisions made just to keep face i.e. transfer  the global Marketing & Knowledge management teams over to Canada - huge expense and not many people made the move 
- there are some exceptions of course but overall management does not lead, they manage (badly) and also no one listens and try to work out why morale is so low

I left after a year, completely gobsmacked by the 'me first' culture I found in this place.

headline: High hopes and expectations, experience fell way short
pros:
1. You join with an intake of like minded people, it is easy to build relationships with other trainees.
2. Lunch allowance.
cons:
1. Study package for ACA delivered by BPP is predominantly delivered remotely, the first face to face college time I had was a year into the training programme. Therefore college time does not also involve developing relationships with colleagues, for many trainees this is a large pull for the job.  
2.  Lack of support for study from engagement managers - many instances of not being given the timetabled study time for the ACA.  Often being told you have too much study for exams the manager thinks are easy (in many instances the manager has completed a different qualification, not the ACA, so do not know what the exams entail).  
3. No work/life balance - most weeks from September to April/May have been 60 hours at least, mainly due to a lack of headcount in the department.
4. Lack of variety for trainees - many trainees stay on the same client for 3 years.  Give trainees a rounded experience of different departments and different industries, this may help retention rates.

headline: KPMG has been a great place to work with opportunities to grow.
pros: People are great here, although it may sound cliche. I really enjoy the caliber of individuals working here and it is great to know that all are committed to quality work. It makes you want to be better.
cons: Work life balance is definitely an area that can be a struggle. The firm will really take what you allow it to, so if you are someone that always completes deadlines on time, looks for new growth opportunities, and goes the extra mile then you will be extremely busy.

headline: Great place to start career, but don't stay over 2-3 years.
pros:
- Friendly coworkers
- Out of Big 4, they seem to care about work life balance more
- Good hours (in Risk Consulting)
- Great benefits (25 days PTO, 401k matching)
- Good training (especially for data programs if you take advantage)
cons:
- You are just a number. They will put you where they need you, irrespective of your skills and interests.
- Partners become protective of resources
- Utilization is #1 metric of your worth
- Salary increases dependent on firm's performance, better to increase your base by going elsewhere then boomeranging back

headline: Great place to work - but be prepared to work hard !
pros:
Quite simply....the people !   The entire company seems to be staffed with very bright, enthusiastic people who all (well...most) have very high degrees of emotional intelligence.  It's a challenging an rewarding place to work.

The wide ranging disciplines can be really useful as well for those wishing to gain experience of multiple industry sectors.  For some there is also an opportunity to travel - although this isn't all good news - it can mean long days travelling but you do get to see some interesing places, meet some fascinating people and experience new cultures and ways of working
cons: The hours can be long...and you can be away from home for long periods of time.  If you like your 9-5 job - then this isn't the company for you.

While this is an important measure to run the business the sole use of this is very evident at yearend and is disheartening because it drives odd behaviors. These behaviors reveal themselves in misalignment with professional development and client goals (e.g. Taking a project that isn't conducive to your development or trying to hang on to a client as long as possible to stay utilized).

headline: KPMG=great company, the IT division really needs an overhaul
pros: Working in IT , you get exposure to very high visbility projects. The IT staff are wonderful, helpful and are very knowledgeable. You can get your teeth into a lot of good technologies working at KPMG. The culture is flexable when it comes to working hours, its a matter of getting the work done on time. The benefits are non existent, but the salary for a lot of staff is above the market rates. Working environments are normally clean and well maintained. Staff of certain levels do get a yearly training budget that he or she is free to choose.
cons:
IT Directorship do not listen to employees at any level. The IT directors dont come from an IT background and hence make huge decisions regarding IT which are almost always bad.  They totally refuse to communicate with senior managers in IT...... for some reason its not in their culture. There is a huge waste of money in the IT sector for little benefit. There is a constant reorg in IT which never seems to work. From the very senior level there is a finger pointing culture when things go inevitability wrong, hence the constant reorgs. The IT staff usually have to complete a lot of tasks undercover out of the view of the directorship.
There is no hope of promotion for anyone that is IT or customer focused.

headline: Know the pros and cons of big 4 before you drink the koolaid.
pros:
It's a great place to be from.

The firm appears to really (truly) care about delivering quality work to clients.

There are some smart cats there.

Good job security (you need to be a complete idiot to lose your job).  

When you turn your LinkedIn button on, recruiters will smash you with offers offering higher pay and significantly better work-life balance.
cons:
Honestly, auditing sucks.  You will spend countless hours with your butt in a chair ticking and tying.  What you studied in college was far more interesting than auditing. 

You will get weird looks for having the gall to take a breather.

You will get treated like a child. Told when you can go to lunch, when you can go home etc...  

You will likely get hit with a soul crushing workload.  Then you will get pulled off of whatever menial task you're working on and told to jump on something else.  Rinse and repeat all day.  

That quality work I mentioned above will come at the expense of your evening and weekend life.

You will drive several hours to count boxes at a warehouse in the middle of nowhere, and be asked to log in that night at the hotel to help out on your current engagement.

You will be asked to sacrifice many weekends; "Oh just log in from home, that is OK!"  

Do not make plans, you are at the complete mercy of your engagement team.

 During campus recruiting, you will be told you will work "normal" hours with the exception of season.  This is a lie.  You have interim, quarterly, and a myriad of other reasons for the team to panic and rack up billable hours. 
This will occur at the drop of a hat too; even when Grandma flew into visit. 

Everything is treated like it is the most important business task in the world.  

Despite all of the warnings you read on the internet, you will drink the koolaid during recruiting and accept the offer.

headline: KPMG- Good learning experience but for a significant cost.
pros: You learn a lot and very quickly. In one year with KPMG, you learn what it takes maybe 1.5 times the time in another work environment. You generally work with young energetic people, and you get to interact with senior level management at client sites. You also get to move around a lot (i.e. you get to travel and work out of different locations). Ther eis a good amount of time off (6 weeks); the starting salary at KPMG (consistent with the Big 4) is higher than in other places. You also get to work independently. After the work is done, also KPMG parties hard, which is fun (work hard, play harder atmoshopher).
cons: The hours can be terrible, but it completely depends on the client you get placed on. Some peoplework a lot more than others, and there is very little recognition between those people. Sure, there are ratings (exceptional performer, vs standard performer), but aside from that, there is a very simal compensation differentiation. Also, you are managed by people who are one year your senior. You could get lucky to work with people who are good, but there is an equal change to work with your seniors who are terrible managers. And, these people, one year your senior, have the power to make your life at KPMG good or terrible. All of your extra effort or lack thereof is seen by your senior but rarely by the executives by the company, so it doesn't pay to put so much effort. The culture assumes that long hours are normal. Someone makes a budget of how many hours something should take, and you have to explain why you went above/below that budget which you didn't really agree with to begin with. THere is pressure to understate hours. Seniors also send you to discuss/argue points with client executives that you don't understand. And you just end up getting yelled at and hated by the client.

headline: Zombie chugging along
pros: Really great benefits that is rare amongst Singapore corporates.
cons:
1. Erroneous hiring process with a focus on hiring from across the causeway or the calibre of mid-career switches.
2. To expound on (1), there was a time when the hires from across the causeway was really value for money as they tend to exhibit a certain level of drive that is uncommon amongst locals BUT these days causeway hires are beginning to exhibit the sort of rent seeking behaviour that junior staffs loathe to see. They work hard back home, get a job here and then decide to just cruise. No longer as driven. Kinda weird phenomenon but I guess it's because it's no longer difficult to secure a job here.
3. SQP is killing the firm as junior staff start to neglect work over their studies.
4. Seems like cruising along will get you an appraisal as good as the other guy who works twice as hard.

headline: Great company if they allowed you to have a life
pros: Intellectually challenging, get to work with different companies in different industries, be part of a team, set career path for promotions, great benefits,
cons: It's great to start off your career but in order to stay long term you have to be willing to give up any control you have over your time whatsoever. Doesn't matter how quickly you get your work done, you won't be able to go home at a normal hour. For some employees the hours are better in the summer but you can also be put on an engagement with a summer year-end which means your busy season can last for most of the year- which equates to 55-95 hour work weeks. It's just not healthy to have to sit at a computer for that many hours a day for 6+ months out of the year. Also gets in the way of time with family, having a social life, love life, etc. Also some offices have a lot of politics and favoritism is given to people with the right connections.

headline: Horrible
pros: Great exposure to various clients.
cons: The group I worked in was not organized well. You were expected to have so many billable hours, but then you would be in trouble if you reported the actual hours you worked. There was NO work life balance. Even if you completed your work, you were expected to sit there until the wee hours of the morning (2am) after getting there at 8am. Then you were also expected to come in on both Saturdays and Sundays regardless of if your work was done or not. The managers had their favorites for staff, who they gave all the big clients to, and then left everyone to figure out how to get their billable hours. The attrition rate in my group was over 80% every busy season. HR knew that this group was an issue, but did nothing about it. Note that the group I reported to was different than others. I had friends in other departments that did not have the same experience.

headline: Great place to work...tough lifestyle!

My performance manager is very candid and good about giving feedback.  He's also great about making sure that I get the right experiences so that I can grown personally and professionally.
cons: Scheduling on projects can be a bit erratic which may at times throw your social/personal life into upheaval.  However, when coming into the industry you have to realize the nature of the beast you're getting yourself into.  Client demands are a significant part of our business.  Nonetheless, I usually find that I can make up the time when I'm in between projects or taking vacation.

headline: KPMG is the lowest class place to work
pros: Maybe a decent name to have on your resume and may look good to some future employers, but that's about it.
cons:
You will get backstabbed, sabotaged, and trampled all over. Coworkers will pull out all the stops to make your life miserable. Even people who are not in direct competition with you will slander you and play all kind of dirty tricks just for sport.  There are only two types of people who can survive long term at KPMG: 

1. Slimeballs who naturally belong in and flourish in a backstabbing toxic work environment. 

2. People who don't mind getting taken advantage of, being stepped all over, and being treated like slaves. 

If you don't fit into the above two categories, this is NOT the place for you. 

It's little wonder that most departments in KPMG are like revolving doors. 

KPMG's bad reputation is very well deserved. It is an absolutely disgusting place to work.

cons:
- As everyone says, work-life balance is less compared to industry.
- Frequent travel as consulting does not work without travel
- If consulting is not your piece of cake better get into industry.

headline: Recommended "Big 4" Public Accounting Firm - Audit, Tax, & Advisory Services
pros:
1) Competitive culture - employees are highly intelligent.  If you are a high performer, you will thrive at KPMG. Bonuses are given if your practice does well.  Also, there's a bonus for high utilization rate.  
2) Excellent trainings including KPMG paying for CPA, CFA, PMP, FRM, CMA, etc. reviews.  Bonus is also given upon passing the exams for CPA license or other certifications.
3) Community service and Diversity/Inclusion activities are highly encouraged and supported.
cons:
1) Salary does not reflect the "High Performance" culture at KPMG.  When an employee gets promoted in July, she/he gets only a little bonus (ie, 2% of base salary).  Although her/his new title is effective as of July, the salary increase is not effective until October. The "little bonus" is supposed to compensate for 3 months.  :(
2) One of the key factors to measure performance is utilization rate.  Although KPMG promotes life balance, the utilization rate goes down when paid-time off (PTO)/vacation are taken.  :(   A company that truly believes in work-life balance will not penalize you for taking your vacation that you earned.

For example, Partner visited client A for the first time after having been on the engagement for 5 years.  Same partner called staff and spent 15 minutes yelling at them while on vacation the day before the staff member's wedding.  The rant was uncalled for and a result of errors made by the Partner.  Nobody takes responsibility for errors in previous year audits.  When you try to correct testing the following year, you are labeled as a trouble maker.  No room for growth.

headline: work experience
pros: great work environment. great gender diversity. great learning experience. great international exposure. great people to work with in serious business environment.
cons:
For Audit/Tax these firms are all very similar. The best way to choose which firm you want to work for is to figure out the culture of the offices in the city you are wanting to work in. The Big 4 have tons of networking events you can go to and meet their team so figuring out which firm you like the best shouldn't be too difficult. Remember that you will be around these people for 80+ hours a week during busy season so it helps a lot if you like your co workers, or can at least tolerate them.

Another thing to factor in is their client base in the city you wish to work in. Many clients hire their auditors after they have a few years under their belt, so if one of the Big 4 has clients that are companies you would like to work for then you may want to choose them.

I have no consulting experience so i cant really speak to that, but i do know that D&T was the only firm who didn't sell their practice after SOX which has given them a leg up on the other 3

headline: For those who like office politics
pros: Flexible hours depending on nature of work. Location is convenient i.e near a shopping mall. Gym membership is good but if you are in audit, you may just use the gym membership for the shower facilities for late night shifts. Less so for other departments e.g Advisory
cons: If you are in audit, be prepared to work longer hours compared to competitors - staff turnover is over the roof as a result of this. Competition is fierce by virtue of high staff volume and they are willing to say or do a lot of things to move up the ladder. Low to zero support from management in terms of morale and guidance especially if your superior is swamped with multiple engagements (some are just plain incapable though). A lot of politics going around across all functions. The Advisory functions are not as competitive as their competitors and their revenue model is the same as Audit - take in any clients as long as targets are met.

headline: Not a good place to Start your Career....
pros: No Pros for this Company... Read the CONS I have got a lengthy List...!  (The Below Relates to TAXATION Department...)
cons:
* KPMG is not at all an Employee Friendly Company..
* No Facilities provided for its Employees... 
* They Treat Employees as their Slaves....! Quite Stupidity, Isn't It?? 
* Even during Non-Season, you will be ORDERED, (Not Requested..!) to Stretch for Long hours without any incentives.
* If you are even getting married during season time, The Managers will ask you to Postpone it.. Horrible...!
* If you are even not feeling well, and have to consult a Doctor, They will not allow you (even you are there for 9 long hours) and ask you to keep all the appointments in weekends, (This being my Personal Experience)
* No Growth in the Company, People here are still Seniors from past 12+ years, (I dont know what they are expecting..!)
* Not at all a better place to work. If you are planning, for KPMG, I Strongly Suggest you not to even Step here....!

I was working harder and delivering more than my entire peer group, yet was not put in line for promotion despite exceeding the relevant criteria. There is a history of racism within the banking tax team in London, and you will rarely see an ethic minority in the team. If you do, they won’t last long! Ruined my experience.

headline: KPMG Management Consulting (MC) is a Stepping Stone to Real MC
pros:
Good people
Not very cut throat
Offices in every large- and mid-sized US city, which provides good mobility for those who need it
Brand new offices
cons:
Their MC practice just doesn't attract A-level talent both at experienced hire level (all levels) or entry level... senior managers who have been jumping ships, managers with no consulting experience, partners who are not selling, etc. What that means is that if you are in MC for experience and learning, KPMG is not going to be able to provide you that. Do yourself a favor and look for MC placement with Booz and Co., ATK, Accenture, etc.

It is also pretty evident from the fact that they mainly end up doing low level (e.g., inventory assessment, spend analysis, etc.) assessment work and little strategy and/or real design and implementation work. 

KPMG MC's financial management practice is somewhat better than their Business Effectiveness practice in terms of higher impact projects, quality of work, quality of talent, etc.

headline: Ambitious, Demanding firm serving minimal attention to employees complaints
pros:
KPMG employs one of the best people on the finance industry where you can meet inspiring and driven people. They have good work ethics and the people they recruit are very heartful and welcoming. 

They pay for all your meals and taxi bills. Something I appreciate since it is rare among korean firms
cons:
The management pushes teams to work too hard, working over 2 am is typical. Taking care of your own health is your own responsibility. nobody hardly skips work on weekends especially if you are working on an offshore project. 

Salary rates are fixed, and there is no room for discussion. (Although they want to hear what you don't like about the company)
Self studying is encouraged but employees are hardly given the opporutnities to use their 15- day holidays a year.

headline: Great team, good company, average pay
pros: The team I work with is by far one of the best - upper management has clear direction and communicates this direction well, I am empowered to deliver my best. The company itself and pay is considered average, but considering how decisions were made to not furlough staff or make anyone redundant during the pandemic, I think this is a great decision that was made by the Exec team - which shows that they value their employees. Alot of headway being made with I&D which is also great. Loads of career opportunities and leadership is always encouraging, challenging staff to explore.
cons: Despite the culture of the company the brand feels a bit old and tired. Pay is pretty average and the bonus amount was small but at least it was something.

headline: Great networking experience, but ultimately felt overworked and underpaid.
pros: Company is young, making it a dynamic and often fun workplace to be. Got great exposure to a variety of different industries and had the opportunity to meet many talented individuals both within KPMG and through client interaction.
cons: It takes at least 3 years to go from Consultant to Senior Consultant, with little to no pay increases year-to-year.  A 60 hour week was not uncommon, with no bonuses or overtime to compensate for extra time spent at the office. Upper management can at times be distant, though this probably varies from department to department.  As a result, turnover is extremely high (thereby keeping the average age of the company quite low).

headline: This is a review for KPMG Global Delivery centre (KGDC) and KGS, not for KPMG India.
pros: There are absolute no pros for working here. Look at the cons if you want to understand how it actually is.
cons: The company runs on the process of buttering up. You keep your seniors impressed, they will look after you, like what used to happen in medieval times ,when kings kept ministers who praised them continuously ,near them. No matter how talented you are & how much work you do, you will be ignored in the end if you don't butter up. The hours are very bad,they will make you stretch for 6 months in a year where as the salary they offer you would be absolutely nothing. You won't get to learn much as well as the company solely relies on outdated tools as the management just wants to keep their pockets heavy. You will end up doing the same monotonous thing, all year around & would be discouraged if you want to learn something new.

headline: Great company to work for to learn business and network
pros:
Being able to work with lots of young, talented, driven, and energetic people.
Ability to work for several different companies and gain an understanding of business processes and activities.
Flexibility to adjust your schedule where needed later in your career.
Steep learning curve gives people the opportunity to be able to make decisions confidently.
Ability to make great relationships with lots of influential people at the clients you serve.
cons:
There are a lot of instances where KPMG halts it's own potential progress with bureaucratic red tape and inability to make a decision and stick with it.
They will work their people a lot harder if their employees allow it and will generally not end up paying what the 'going rate' for their employee experiences really is (i.e. they will be paying what the other Big 4 firms pay, or at least close, but because that is what the other firms pay doesn't necessarily mean that's the market rate for those same people).
There are a lot of administrative requirements that become more and more evident, that take away from what people truly enjoyed doing earlier in their careers, as you progress with the firm.
No true 'upside' to doing your job well in terms of seeing rewards for doing a job better in the current year than what was done in the prior years (speaking specifically to profitability, efficiency, or client relationships).

headline: No work life balance
pros: There is no shortage of work.
cons: Always understaffed. KPMG does not care about its employees- they are only concerned with profits for those at the top of the structure.  They also do not provide broad experience.  You get locked into a specific service line and it is difficult to find rotations in different practices.

headline: Work hard, play hard
pros: Benefits are great. The opportunity to work with people at the top of their field, any support or advice you need is at the touch of your fingers, and as a whole, the company truly cares about their people. Overall I can say that I’m thankful and enjoyed my 7+ years with the firm...the hours can be long and the work is challenging...but you learn a ton and frankly, overtime is of the part of the deal when you’re in public accounting.
cons: We’re talking about a Big 4 public accounting firm...obviously long hours for most of the year. Although they have tried to improve their 401(k) contributions, it’s still almost a joke at how little they are willing to match. Also, singles watch out...unless you have children, you can kiss work/life balance away. However, if you’re an accountant thinking about working at KPMG, don’t be mislead...this is standard across ALL public accounting firms. The adage is true — the PEOPLE you work with make the difference and the overtime, work, and benefits are pretty standard across the board.

headline: KPMG good and bad
pros:
- Good Employee benefit in terms of PTO, material leave, and career development - It is easy to switching service line and KPMG provide lots of option to employee who wants to leave the firm so that they can keep the human resource and direct the employee to another service line or etc to get another opportunity. (They put tremendous efforts to reduce employee turnover ratio) 
- Full of resource where you can easily find accounting and auditing information 
- Lots of fun events that support employee's moral
- Flexible schedule
cons:
- Time constraint work environment 
- Most of time it is likely to work during the weekend (Sometimes we have to make impossible to possible) 
- Engagement does not end when fieldwork is done. Follow up always happens after the fieldwork.
- As you goes upper level, you will probably face lots of admin work and it is very tidious.

headline: Great brand recognition and industry expertise
pros:
-KPMG provide training all year around, with up to 3 weeks training the 1st year
-Senior management is easily accessible and comes to supervise the projects directly with the team and the clients
-Teamwork is awesome during the 1st year among new auditors/consultants
-KPMG is the leader in the French market and has contracts with high profile companies
-It is easy to work accross different business and functions. I was recruited in the Financial Services Business Unit as and auditor but I had the opportunity to work with the Transaction Services division and I was also involved in consulting projects
-You need to be proactive to get the best projects.
-You may have the opportunity to supervise projects and interact with top exécutives at an early stage.
cons:
-The job may be really stressful and I was expected to finish work during the weekend without billing it in some occasions
-A lot gossiping, hypocrrisy,backstabbing and ''dirty politics" from juniors to senior management. It was hard to trust anyone there
-Hardword and meritocracy  are not recognised. Instead, you are expected to interact well and please project managers in order to get good feedback and get promoted.

headline: Very good school for beginning career.
pros: international environment, friendly atmosphere, focus on internal training, open communication, work-life balance applicable mostly in non-audit related services, salary level high compared to average
cons: very long hours in audit season, sometimes pressure from outside is not managed well internally.

headline: A great place to work and build a career.
pros:
KPMG provides a plethora of opportunities to participate in and work on varying engagement types, both locally and internationally.    Firm employees have every opportunity to chart out their career growth paths, and are encouraged along these lines by periodic discussions with their performance managers about where they are, where they want to be, and what they need to get there.  The firm provides great training opportunities both online and instructor led course; and in fact KPMG mandates that employees complete a specified number of CPE hours yearly.  In line with career growth and education opportunities, the firm provides great mobility.  If for whatever reason find that you need to move to another city, or country for that matter, they will work with you to identify a position in that location.  If you wish to try living and working in another country, KPMG regularly offers secondment opportunities that you can apply for.  

The firmâ??s focus on professionalism and integrity is abundantly clear from recruitment and through your career at KPMG.  Salaries seem fair and benefits are\were great.  Work/Life balance did not seem like just talk, the firm makes an effort to not to drive you to the ground.  They make very reasonable accommodations and provide flexible or alternate work schedules.  They also have great community outreach and volunteer groups.
cons:
Be prepared to work long hours/days at crunch time.  This can be quite stressful and taxing for some.  Travel can be quite challenging.  Depending on the team/line of business you are in, you could spend 3-4 days a week away from home, back on the weekend and its back on the plane again on Sunday in order to be at the client site Monday morning, bright eyed and bushy tailed.  Itâ??s amazing how all airports, cities and hotels start looking alike.  There have been times when I have woken up in the middle of the night and could not remember what city I was in.  Travel can really be hard on the family.  I know folks whose relationships/marriages have gone up in smoke because of this.  Of course when home for the weekend i.e. Friday evening through Sunday afternoon, you have your â??crackberryâ? mobile device with you in order to respond promptly to client/team requests.

On a parting note, you may be good at what you do, but as you leave the Associate or Senior Associate ranks and join management, be prepared to start selling.  You will be expected to bring in work and the firm sets the dollar amount that you are to hit.  You may be the biggest, baddest investigator/accountant, once you hit management, you are going to have to be a sales person and start focusing on business developement.  I have known good people that have lost their jobs because they do not sell well, but are otherwise great people managers.  

Compensation does get better though.

Also, senior managers are not always entirely truthful.  Be sure to have your BS filter tuned to high when talking with them.

headline: Poor experience for Directors and MD levels
pros: Provide solid remuneration, average big consulting bonuses, and good transitions on-board, off-boarding.
cons: Difficult to achieve targets, poor internal processes and controls, terrible systems, in-fighting galore between groups and even amongst people at close levels over credit, and almost no collaboration. Unscrupulous behaviors are a challenge relative other accountancies who do “Big 4” consulting (i.e., firing of account leaders for unethical behavior). Some of the worst performers are there and continue to be there due to fear of lawsuits, corporate cronyism and absolute fear of actively dealing with the worst employees who occupy protected classes.

headline: Not the right culture for me
pros: High pay for no experience, travel if you want it, lots of happy hours if you want them
cons: Being idle is rewarded, so long as you show face at your client. I tried to leave before 9pm after they ran out of work for me to do, and was penalized for it. The people who work here sadly think that this is normal. Work/life balance isn't in their vocabulary. I once asked for an example of work/life balance and my interviewer told me that the company let him take off to see his wife in labor. If he was thankful for that time off, what's the point of having a kid? But I'm sure he'll make a good living. I'd rather live my life and be a little less wealthy than eat dinner at the office for 10 months of the year.

headline: Audit Senior Associate
pros: So I was promoted to senior and shortly quit. However,  I was in audit for 2 years. KPMG itself has great perks (that I think are better than other big four firms). I was in audit, so there was more cons to pros. The firm itself is GREAT on per diem. So if you are traveling a lot, plan on making some good $$ just from per diem. The people are bright, yet chill, which I really like. Although I am at a different big four firm in a different practice all together, KPMG will always be my favorite.
cons: Downsides of working in AUDIT (not KPMG). The hours are LONG, the pay is LOW and the work is boring. You are testing things that already happened and are so deep in the weeds, that you lose sight of the big picture. There is high turnover, always low on staff. If you are working on a public engagement, beware. Those are the worst hours by far. It will be hard to stay fit during busy season because you literally will have breakfast, lunch, dinner plus snacks during your 15+ hour day.  Other cons (that is specific to audit, NOT KPMG) is that it's hard to transfer out of Audit. I tried to do so and I would have had to wait another busy season and another year and a half to see an increase in salary and a permanent change in position. That is why I left the firm.

Pay- KPMG being a younger big 4 is a little low on the pay scale as compared to the other big 4 firms.

headline: Audit Associate
pros:
-Working with amazing, kind, hard working co-workers. Most people I interacted with on the job were of the highest caliber. 
-Clear job path.
cons:
-They intentionally understaff teams. There is always far more work than people to do it, meaning that people have to perpetually work long hours.
-The hours. Often it's in order to make a tight deadline. But people would regularly still stayed late even if there was no pressing deadline and the manager said, "don't stay late tonight." 
-Middle management tends to justify the long hours by saying something along the lines of, "The team at Client X has it worse. They haven't had a weekend of this month! You should be thankful that we only have to work on Saturday."  
-Because of the hours, people tend to not have any outside hobbies.
-The work hours are mostly spent in silence in a conference room (which may or may not have windows depending on the client), staring at Excel sheets. Not super stimulating stuff.

headline: Great place to start your career, but ...
pros:
1. Good place to start your career, lots of exposure to different projects
2. Colleagues are willing to help and good culture
3. Management are still very approaching 
4. Work life balance and work pressure is acceptable and hand-able (compared to big tech firms or other consulting firms). You might need to work overtime during the workday, and very rarely during the weekend (usually when there is a deadline)
5. Great reputation and great career platform, many colleagues end up going to big tech firms after KPMG
6. Firm in general care about their employee (we do not have lay off yet)
cons:
1. Pay you lower than the market value
2. No bonus, no 401K, no raise, due to COVID, also projects are getting worse (less time to charge, less interesting) since COVID
3. you learning rate decrease drastically after 1 year in the firm (projects start to get similar)
4. project are not always "machine learning", many are data manipulation / business analytical work
5. No control of your next project, you never know what you will get (like a box of chocolate)
6. You ended up knowing little bit across different industry, which can be bad for career development in the long run

headline: Was a good place to work for IT
pros: I spent 5 years working for KPMG, got involved in several very high profile projects, I learned a lot while at the company.  Work level was high but tolerable and I had no problem maintaining a good work/life balance.
cons: KPMG at some point got it in their heads that it would be a good idea to outsource their whole IT department, brought in a new CTO and simply cut positions without regard to who knew what at the firm.  I believe the criteria was "we need X people in this group, hold onto the most senior based upon time with the company and get rid of everybody else"  I served to reduce the headcount but several years later KPMG is still paying the price for the short sighted move to outsource.

headline: Great people, horrible internal processes
pros:
- Great team members and overall company culture 
- Good benefits and PTO 
- Large variety of clients to be staffed on
- Very clear promotion path (assoc > sr. assoc > mgr > etc.)
cons:
- Poor work/life balance
- Expected to "check-in" and still work if needed while on PTO 
- Encouraged to use your voice but very rarely actually listened to 
- Since all of your work hours go to client work, you're expected to participate in a number of "internal initiatives" in your evening hours, and if you don't, they'll hold it against your promotion 
- Internal processes are horrific (HR, Accounting Center, tech support, etc.) - if you want to actually use the benefits it's a nightmare to deal with, everything requires mass amounts of pre and post-approval from all ranks of leadership, it's all just very poorly run for such a big company and causes a ton of headaches and extra work
- They make it sound easy to internally switch groups but it's actually near impossible to make horizontal moves. If you are able to, it takes almost half a year to get anywhere and you have to figure it all out yourself

headline: Senior Audit Associate

headline: "Get Some Experience then Get Out" - This is my advice
pros:
- Some really nice colleagues who help you through the day
- The notion that a big company will look good on your CV
cons:
- Low-salary (even for Eastern-European standards) which the company tries to compensate with cafeteria bills and other garbage to save you a few pennies
- Repetitive workload 
- You basically just have to learn stuff off-by-heart / no logic or thinking is required. You have to turn your brain into a computer and do the same stuff over and over again.
- Promotions are very hard to get and most people drop out when they witness the truth: it's just not worth all the hustle for this salary.

headline: Working environment
pros:
KPMG as part of their work culture conducts thorough and in depth analysis during audit process for its clients. 
You almost know everybody in your audit department group. Everyone is friendly there and as such there is no negativity with regards to working with your peers.
cons:
Working late nights is the norm here. If you are not working beyond 8pm that means you are not working seriously.
One of the major default in their working is that audit staff has IT admin passwords which they use to change time and date to allow audit documentation beyond deadlines. I haven't encountered any such instance but anyone can heavily misuse the password to bring down the entire KPMG network with it. Everyone in the audit from associate/ article trainee to the partner knows about sharing of IT admin password and they don't care

There is NO clean desk policy. They have a policy but just in papers. You can see audit and tax files lying all around office. If one wants to intentionally seek out any information regarding public companies, it is quite easy, just grab any file in the office lying around and 4 out of 10 times you may come across information about a public company. And there are no cameras to see who is looking for the information. If you are worried about being caught by other co-workers then just come to office on a Sunday of late night after 12am.
Apart from potential fraud opportunities, not following the clean desk policy makes the KPMG office seem like a govt. office and just reduces the quality of work environment. You just sometimes don't feel like working there.

headline: KPMG
pros: The best reasons to work at KPMG include: 25 days vacation, training, advancement opportunities, benefits package, breadth of resources, mobility, various projects and assignments, and complete benefits package
cons: The downsides of working at KPMG include: Depending on the engagement, the jobs entails long hours. Also, all client engagements vary. Some are more challenging and interesting than others.

headline: Worst of the Big 4
pros: The best thing about it is that it is a "Big 4" firm.  You can carry the name and people will give it weight because of it.
cons: It's the smallest of the Big 4 and KPMG makes concessions regarding price (unlike PWC who does not give discounted rates).  So, engagement teams eat their hours all the time to not go over budget but they run the risk of getting laid off due to low utilization. They accept clients that require lots of manual hours of data entry so they push the data entry to the staff rather than sending that work to the India Q center where it belongs so the crop of people moving up don't know anything about tax.  PWC has internal proprietary software that cuts the data entry to a fraction of the time KPMG would spend giving it the staff to do, which frees up the PWC staff to actually learn more important concepts. The quality of training is a joke.  No one in senior management and above really cares about your career, so watch your back.  Being on the client side now and seeing PWC work my employer's account, I can see the difference in training and quality.  I would not recommend choosing KPMG over the other Big 4 firms.

headline: A Changed Firm
pros:
Good benefits
Good learning ground
Good for out of college
Some good folks still around...but do not know for how long
cons:
This is as of new KPMG ...after reorg -
Terrible promotion process
Terrible year end review process
Really no value of emploees anymore
More and more turning into a sweat shop
Requiring folks to work 50 hours a week Aug - Feb (starting this year), used to be Oct - Jan/Feb before

The promotion process has become absolutely unfair. The partners are working to cover their own favorites and promote them. 

Know so many of my experienced colleagues from all grades (Associates, Senior Associates, Manager and Sr. Mgrs) who are just waiting for an opportunity to jump.

With rollout of the automated tools, the vision is towards outsourcing alot of audit related jobs.

headline: Exit at first opportunity
pros:
Great place to start a career.  You are not building a career at KPMG, you are building your career outside of KPMG.  The marketplace does recognize the value of Big 4 experience and it will be realized upon exit.
25 days of vacation is nice...but can you actually use them?
cons:
you get vacation but using it is hard.  If you use it, you feel bad as performance metics hurt you for using the vacation the firm gives you.  Overall messaging is "do not use vacation and be a high performer or use it and be a under-performer"
Egos get in the way ALL THE TIME!  Horrible teamwork.  Worst self-interest I have ever been around.

Overall the culture could be summarized as ‘a sinking ship’.

headline: Good enough
pros:
KPMG as a big firm gives you the chance to try different areas. They are quite flexible when it comes to move towards another area after even 6 months. (better that than they lose you ;) )

If you are the kind of person looking for a "safe job" and get a reasonable salary comparing with Portugal's mean, you will be fine at KPMG. (not so good , because of extra hours tho).

Health insurance and Vodafone perks.
cons:
If you get out of a top university in Portugal and you look for something exciting, just go abroad and start in any consulting company instead. When it comes to salary Portugal's tax system is not attractive and wages are low. Apart from that in KPMG Portugal, the consulting mindset is completely distorted. You will not step up on your career based on your effort. There are minimum years required in each level. So even though you are amazing you will end up have to wait 3 to 4 years to step up.

Work-life balance isn't the worst, but still sucks. And keep in mind OVER WORK IS NOT PAID.

headline: Good company, Bad job
pros: The best reasons to work at KPMG have to be the vacation time and the opportunity to advance both within the company and elsewhere. The Company tries to do little things to make the employees feel valued (gifts, extra days off, parties, etc), but it often doesn't make a significant impact. Management seems to care and most of the people are genuinely good people with the best intentions.
cons: The work itself is awful. The hours during the spring are ridiculous and there is an expectation that working all the time is expected and is something to admire. Work should support one's life, work should not be one's life. The vacation time is nice (25 days), but it is necessary to endure the constant irritation that is the average day at work.

headline: Great company for progression

headline: Please don't join the Risk Team - KGS
pros:
Onshore team is good.They listen you and also provide you the guidelines for your career growth.
Very frequent parties with onshore team members.
Get chance to work with multiple teams if you want to work and show eagerness to work.
cons:
KGS is like a call center of KPMG US/UK. Here your career depends totally on how is your relationship with your manager

HR don't take any action. I showed the proof that my manager took so many leaves and didn't put in the leave system but no action has been taken against her.

Now a days there is lot of politics, favoritism and corruption in the KGS risk team. Director don't know what is consulting and they are leading consulting projects.

Compare to industry standard they pay very less and expect you to work 14-16 hours daily.
Even on holidays also. You don't have a personal life, even if you want leave on your any friend or relative death. They simply deny. But if you manager have little bit cold and cough, your manager is entitle to take complete day leave without putting the same in the leave system.

Leave system of KGS is really worse. They don't know how to trace whether employee came to office or not.

And during the appraisal time, they show you that you are not worth at all.
Manager lack technical and communication skills.

If KPMG management didn't take any corrective action, we will see KGS scandal or MMS very soon in the coming time.

headline: Long hours, stingy salaries, unreasonable project deadlines, and stressful work environment
pros: Working for KPMG proves that you are a strong candidate with the ability to roll up your sleves and get the job done. You also get access to the books and records of some very reputable clients that provide meaningful experience for your career later on down the line. The other professionals working with you are you're greatest resource and are exceptional friends and colleagues.
cons:
Prepare to have no life outside of work. Never in my life could I have ever imagined working this much. You work on weekends, sometimes 7 days a week, often times without charging the time or getting recognized for putting in the effort to meet unreasonable budget and time deadlines that your managers will never commend you on. Prepare for 40-55 hr work weeks during summer and 80-100+ hr work weeks from September-April. 

Your clients will never be pleased to see you, no matter how good you are, and they will in fact make that known to you at all times. Some are often very difficult to work with or get the right information from. 

On top of everything, the salaries they are offering are much lower than the mid tier firms for some unknown reason and when you calculate the number of hours you put in compared to your pay you might be making somewhere near $12/hr while they charge the client $350/hr for your services.

They give you 25 days PTO but implemented 7 days of mandatory PTO, further reducing your paid vacation/sick time to about 18 days. Its not uncommon to get bad performance reviews for taking PTO at times that are not advantageous to the firm. For example, if you book a vacation a year in advance and due to client push back the engagement doesn't finish on time but you leave for vacation, that will negatively be frowned upon no matter how out of your hands the situation may be.

headline: Great People, but lack of recognition for staff
pros: KPMG has an innate ability to find amazing people, who make coming to work a pleasure. We are exposed to some of the world's largest institutions and get a unique experience to see into industry while remaining outside.
cons: Compensation, bonuses, and performance reviews are becoming more and more opaque. Recent business and billing challengers seem to affect staff-level professionals with seemingly little consequences to leadership, who have the responsibility to be in the market and win work.

headline: Interesting work, shame about the bureaucracy
pros: Reasonable work life balance, interesting client work, good internal referral network, a range of teams with different specialisms with infighting kept to lower levels than at the competition.
cons: Inconsistency between claims of wanting to hear feedback and then viewing such as troublemaker behaviour. There is also an expectation management problem on salaries and what actual levels are. Meritocracy is sometimes lacking, with East Asian features or a Chinese surname helping several career paths prematurely.

headline: Management Consultant
pros: You are surrounded by smart, dynamic individuals and leaders who you will build strong and support relationships with. You receive wonderful benefits and work in a lovely office. There is also a little bit of flexibility with working arrangements.
cons: You are a slave to the work and there is still no real way of managing the chaos of client demands and the flow of work that comes from that i.e. chargeable v. BD v. everything else. Everything is last minute and not planned. Which means you work to tough deadlines and ultimately deliver a quality of work that you aren't happy with. This is not Agile/MVP/Safe-to-fail, it is simply unorganised. Working arrangements are flexibility, but is mostly directed at senior leaders who have the salary to drop back days or individuals with families. It is still frowned upon to WFH or less then 5 days if under Manager though it is encouraged?

headline: I was part of the audit and assurance department for over 4 years.

Exposure in variety of roles, complex issues, etc in short span of time. Rewarding in terms of knowledge and also to a certain extent pay.

headline: Worst among the Big 4

Individual goal driven practice....lacks cooperation as a firm.
HR has no effective control or role in the system.
No capacity building or investment in innovative thinkers. 
It's more of factory than a professional firm.

headline: They can do better
pros:
- Great chance to follow a lot of different projects, learning fast and improving your CV
- Managers are highly qualified and really available in supporting you in developing new skills
- Even during the 2008-2009 crisis no one was discharged
- Senior consultants are given a healthcare insurance
cons:
HR management highly improvable:
- few team building opportunities
- really low salary compared with public commpanies
- overtime is not directly paid (but bonuses are provided at year end)
- Company car is provided but you are requested to pay around 150-180 € per month
- Some time you will be required to work from 10-14 hours a day for a long period (1-3 months) or to work during week-ends
- no international training opportunities. Internal training is not so good (the average duration of a course is 1 day)
- few opportunities of having an international experience working for other international KPMG entities
- meal tickets are not provided and a cafeteria service is not available

headline: Work Environment

headline: KPMG: Partnership of Favoritism
pros: Many interesting and genuine colleagues provide guidance and assistance.
cons: Highly political and little job security. Often people are promoted on the strength of their ability to network with the right partner or higher echelon director and with little regard to their talent or credentials. If you do not have a partner protector you are in dangerous waters. I was part of a group that was let go because one notorious partner wanted to get rid of one employee so to cover his tracks he let go of the entire group of 20.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Good reputation and good for the CV
cons: Exceedingly long hours and you end up working in your free time all the time. Salaries are not great

headline: Run far away from this place
pros: Name recognition, WFH stipend, 401k match, Travel opportunities
cons: Horrible insurance - my new company's insurance is 1/5th the cost with 5x the coverage. Relocating is nearly impossible. Rotating to other teams is also nearly impossible. The culture is extremely toxic. Seniors and managers will tell you to your face you did a good job on something, only to tear you to shreds behind your back to the partners. Utilization goals and work life balance are both impossible. You will not realize how horrible it is to work at this company until you leave. I received more respect working in fast food than I did here. Leadership is the opposite of transparent. We were not informed about layoffs until 8am on the morning of layoffs. This company pays plenty of money to get ranked highly on different workplace rating articles, but let me assure you they view you as an input of labor and nothing else. Management does a horrendous job of planning out engagements and will always have you working until 3am the night before something is due, even if they knew about the deadline months in advance. The pay is obscenely below market and the bonus structure is pathetic.

headline: Consulting - bottom of the Big 4
pros: Advisory side is not that strong so there's much opportunity for market leaders of various expertise
cons: Quality is remarkably and visibly lower than the other top consulting firms. I regretted coming over as there were very few proprietary developed methodologies or intellectually innovative content. Also I did observe this is not a highly diverse company and/or tranparent when it comes to performance management. I had two HR cases filed that were never brought to a conclusion while and after I transitioned out of the firm.

headline: Manager
pros: A liberal employer that treats you fair and based on your performance.
cons: For people who are not proactive it may lead to frustration that you have to work and deserve your way up. Exceptions confirm this rule.

headline: good place to learn

cons: long hours; high pressure; no work life balance

headline: GReat company to work for

cons: Very big organisation and large teams, so it is perhaps not as easy to connect to people and feel the team, like it would be in smaller teams. It has positive sides to it though as well.

headline: Low Pay for Hours Toiled
pros: Looks okay on a resume because it is a recognized brand name since it is one of the Big Four firms.
cons: My supervisor called me at home when I was very sick and wanted me to work on a project from my house.  He knew I was using a sick day.  This also happened to some of my coworkers, and not just during crunch time, but throughout the year.  We were given projects that were impossible to finish in the hours we were allowed to bill.  A very fatiguing experience.  I was lied to a lot when people were playing politics.

headline: Work life balance

cons: busy season, hours, salary pay

headline: KPMG Verifications (Yerwada, Pune)
pros: Nice employees to work with
cons: Employees are treated like robots, high work pressure, minimal pay. Randomly on Thursdays they announce that Saturday is working with no incentives/ bonus. You won't learn anything here and there's limited growth. It's really hard to switch into another department, feels like a call center. Although they won't label this office as a BPO, it's probably worse than working at a BPO. Oh, and if you're late to lunch, don't expect there to be any food left in the canteen.

headline: Lions lead by donkeys
pros: the people on the ground are by and large fantastic.  Very easy going with respect to supporting work life balance.

headline: KPMG is a great place to start your career
pros: KPMG is a great name to have on your resume.  There are a wide pool of individuals which you can learn something from.  KPMG is also a great place to meet people and network.  KPMG also offers extensive training and 25 paid days off a year in addition to holidays.
cons: Often, you may find yourself working long hours.  There is no overtime pay for salaried individuals.  Since there are so many other staff members, you will really need to set yourself apart from the rest in order to move up beyond the senior associate level.

headline: Managing Consultant

cons: Heavy travel (Mon-Thurs every week); limited input in staffing opportunities; no expert/alternative career tracks for lower level consultants

headline:

headline: Good place to learn but not necessarily grow

headline: A Dream Come True
pros:
Often in films, you see these wonderful companies with incredible teams. In my entire career, I saw only the opposite when working at some smaller local companies with multiple job hats at a single location . . .When I came here, it was a night and day difference where at times I sometimes still have trouble comprehending where I'm at! KPMG is incredible!

At KPMG, I truly feel the company and team cares about you as a person. The talent you get to work with is like no other from my experience all being rock stars in their own areas. You'll find this in every team there and get the opportunity to work with other groups. The company is constantly investing into employees and their well being whether it be from training to some fun activities including ski retreats. The quality that comes from here is amazing too and you'll find your team pushing you to your limits. KPMG has so many talented folks that care and has such a clear vision of the future that I feel like this is a second home or second family.
cons: Sometimes there can be a bit of work/life off balance but when it's brought up to a manager, they quickly fix it.

headline: Strikes the right work/life balance
pros: Awesome work life balance can be found at KPMG. With 25 personal paid days off a year plus the eight or so holidays, there is always plenty of time to spend with friends and family. In general, most of the people in the workplace are smart, kind, and interesting, although there are quite a few "corporates" that treat work like a political battleground.
cons: It's easy to get comfortable with all the perks and hard to get off and leave. It is possible to stagnate. I also feel that some of the skills I develop, "technical" or not might not really apply outside the workplace...so how can I possibly leave one day?

headline: This is a good place to work if you like staid, stodgy, and conservative work cultures.
pros: KPMG has good name recognition in Singapore and globally, so it is not bad to have on your resume. Other employers have a lot of familiarity with the Big 4 firms.
cons: The business environment in Singapore is modernizing. The management of KPMG recognizes this, but KPMG is very slow to react. We say we want to provide excellent client service, but we're too conservative to give advice that is much help, and our various departments cannot work together because each partner is too selfish to sacrifice fees by working with other partners.

headline: Great working environment
pros: Employees of KPMG agree that most of the persons working in this company are very friendly, helpful and get along very well no matter from what country they come. The company encourages integrity, openness and pays great attention to the well-being of its employees. Good opportunities to raise up the career ladder and for personal/professional development, but not for niche positions. A number of company and team parties, fruit days, possible bonuses.
cons: Mostly seasonal job - hours and days of overtime during the season after the end of financial year, and very little to 0 work during out of season period. Low chance to get vacations in spring. Sometimes there is lack of planning, too much pressure to finish tasks when they are transferred from audit for formatting and similar. I'm pretty sure they should invest more in planning so they would evade many hours of overtime.

headline: Internal audit trainee at KPMG Hungary
pros: I have spent 4 month working as a trainee at KPMG Hungary, Internal Audit Risk & Compliance Services department. I think KPMG is a fine choice for launching your career. The development is constant and the projects are interesting. I would especially recommend for people bearing some agricultural background knowledge or those who have particular interest in this field as the Hungarian office deals with the audit of many agricultural EU subsidies. The team is great and there are many out of office activities all year round.
cons: KPMG's business model in Hungary seems to be a bit different from the other Big4 firms here: they employ many trainees who help the relatively small number of full-time workers. The salary is just ok compared to other positions on the market but definitely lower than the Big4 average.

headline: Terrible co-workers. Even worse human beings.
pros: OK compensation but simply blood money. Good on resume and to prove some base level of competence in interviews.
cons: Unprofessional. Deal advisory people are self-righteous, petty and glorified accountants. Think they are PE guys, investment bankers, or strategists. Umm you're work is an overpriced commodity. You're the tiniest stage of a deal. You over deliver work at low fees because you're a commodity, and then bash people on budgets, even after asking teams to do more work than what's in scope. Don't care for a minute about your life, family or well being. Openly curse at and about people. Don't develop people and bash when they don't perform to perfection. Love data people and even then, are treated like a slave. While now leading a team in industry, I'll never hire them because I don't support slave labor.

headline: KPMG is a great place to work - However, auditing is not really a rewarding career - That was my experience
pros: Strong support to help pass UFE exam.  Excellent people.  As far as audit firms go, I would recommend KPMG in Vancouver.  KPMG paid overtime during my first two years, which for me was essentially travel time.  I was fortunate to get the opportunity to travel within Canada, USA, Central America and Africa.  These experiences alone were great.  However, KPMG is big enough, that if you don't want to travel, there are plenty of local jobs.
cons: Auditing was not a rewarding job for me personally.  This is not a KPMG specific negative - it is more of a job specific negative.  Basically, regardless of how well you build relationships with clients, they are always happy to see you leave at the end of the audit.  I didn't enjoy that part of the job.

headline: Work hard, play hard
pros: Great people to work with, above average pay and a continuous drive in every one around you to improve both personally and professionally
cons: high-pressure, demanding lengthy time commitments and the ability to manage multiple projects at once can sometimes take a toll on your personal life - but KPMG manages the nature of this work far better than other firms

headline: Comparable intern experience with friends in the other Big 4
pros:
All your travel and overtime meal expenses are reimbursed. There is per diem. Pretty standard for a large, multinational firm like KPMG, but hey, it's nice to have so that you're not paying for business costs out of your own pocket.
KPMG also gives full time Associates 25 vacation/sick days each year. This is addition to 8 days of firm holiday that everyone gets off.
cons: Although the internship salary was comparable with the other Big 4, KPMG pays its full time Associates about 2k less than its competitors in the Big 4.

headline: Absolutely NO work-life balance when on a project.
pros:
People you work with are great, never had an issue with anyone.
Everybody is always MORE than willing to help when you have a work related issue/problem.
cons:
You are on-site with the client 90% of the time. So work conditions vary immensely. Work hours are horrendous. You are expected to work 12+ hour shifts. Some nights can extend to 3-4 AM with little empathy from managers.

Also don't expect a single dime for any overtime.

headline: One of the best places to work - KPMG!
pros:
Diversity, emphasis on work/life balance, open and honest communication at all times and most importantly - THE AWESOME PEOPLE!
There is also a great emphasis on work hard and play harder.  There is an emphasis on the career development of women.  The firm provides excellent training, inside and outside.  Whatever you choose to do, it is a great place to start your career at and then maybe go into the industry, gains ome experience of a different sort and then come back here and keep rising upwards.  They will take you back with open arms because they encourage diversity of thought and experience as well.
cons:
It is afterall an industry that requires long hours and sometimes during busy season you do put in 60 hour weeks regularly.  However, this is not restricted to KPMG alone.  It is something seen all Big 4 firms.
In all Big 4 firms, such as this one, there are times of the year when companies are filing their financial statements and things tend to get really hectic and exhausting.  However, a firm like KPMG also gives you 25 paid days off!  They encourage you to take all your time off as and when needed.  So while there is a downside, the salary, bonus, and other benefits compensate for it.

cons: Internal politics can be frustrating, and partnership can be a bit of an old boys network in places. headline: Exhausting, frustrating and unrecognized
pros:
Obviously the largest benefit of working at KPMG is the fact that it is a Big 4 Audit firm. Having KPMG on your resume is attractive and can be beneficial to your career growth.

Furthermore, I was very satisfied with the salary and benefits in my position.
cons:
In my division, there was very little recognition and management often spoke down to associates. I felt that my input was not appreciated.

Furthermore, I was not the least bit challenged by my work. I spent most of my time editting existing documents and creating excel sheets. Management told me exactly how they wanted work to be completed and there was no room for flexibility. I felt there was no room for innovation and I never had the opportunity to bring my own contributions.

Staffing on projects was rarely done by interests or expertise. As an associate, I was placed where I was needed and not where I was getting the development I needed. Furthermore, the company continued to hire industrial/organizational psychologists for technology implementation projects. Many of my peers and myself were bored by our projects because it did not relate to our backgrounds.

cons: a lot of hours on the job

headline: KPMG- Good learning experience but for a significant cost.
pros: You learn a lot and very quickly. In one year with KPMG, you learn what it takes maybe 1.5 times the time in another work environment. You generally work with young energetic people, and you get to interact with senior level management at client sites. You also get to move around a lot (i.e. you get to travel and work out of different locations). Ther eis a good amount of time off (6 weeks); the starting salary at KPMG (consistent with the Big 4) is higher than in other places. You also get to work independently. After the work is done, also KPMG parties hard, which is fun (work hard, play harder atmoshopher).
cons: The hours can be terrible, but it completely depends on the client you get placed on. Some peoplework a lot more than others, and there is very little recognition between those people. Sure, there are ratings (exceptional performer, vs standard performer), but aside from that, there is a very simal compensation differentiation. Also, you are managed by people who are one year your senior. You could get lucky to work with people who are good, but there is an equal change to work with your seniors who are terrible managers. And, these people, one year your senior, have the power to make your life at KPMG good or terrible. All of your extra effort or lack thereof is seen by your senior but rarely by the executives by the company, so it doesn't pay to put so much effort. The culture assumes that long hours are normal. Someone makes a budget of how many hours something should take, and you have to explain why you went above/below that budget which you didn't really agree with to begin with. THere is pressure to understate hours. Seniors also send you to discuss/argue points with client executives that you don't understand. And you just end up getting yelled at and hated by the client.

You'll learn a lot about how to work with people through your job here.  The vacation days are great: 25 days a year - that's hard to beat anywhere!
cons: Sometime, office politic can be bothersome.  The review process can be subjective as well.  Also be aware that consulting schedule is unpredictable: long hours and high pressure on some days, normal and relax atmosphere on other days.  The biggest downsides is that in certain group, staffs are not challenged enough.

headline: HR assistant- The HR department was very administrative
pros: Free lunch allowance daily -
cons:
Salary was very low compared to other companies in Hertfordshire

The managers do not understand what HR is. They fired all the temps with no notice and two weeks later they were on the phone begging them back.

The turnover in HR is so high, literally everyweek is someone's leaving lunch.

HR roles are very administrative and i would not recommend anyone to work there, especially if they already have HR experience.

So much backlog you will be dealing with email from about two months ago.

However the other departments are better especially if you are client facing.

headline: Great brand but be careful if you’re joining BPG
pros: Very ethical with a focus on corporate social responsibility. Benefits are solid. KPMG takes care of their client service professionals and provides career growth and opportunity. Audit has a strong reputation in the industry. Work-life balance is valued as much as possible in a seasonal business with the option to take sabbaticals and 25 days of PTO.
cons: Little growth or advancement if you are on corporate/non-client facing (BPG) team. People stay in the same roles for years and years, often becoming stale and ineffective. BPG is full of former client facing folks that often didn’t cut it on that side or wanted more work-life balance so moved over to internal operations. It's difficult to make any sort of impact unless you have a prior client service background, even if you are well-educated and qualified for your role.  As big firms often are, it is a very political environment and often not inclusive. High performers tend to leave because there isn’t a strong pay for performance model which  encourages mediocrity. People are often promoted that are not ready because they have been around long enough or are friends with the right people.

headline: Tough but you learn a lot

Constant professional development from KPMG's internal business school. 
Guranteed to help you pass the exams once you put in any effort.
The other trainees make the transistion to working life easier.
The firm is very social.
Always at the forefront of accounting standards.
cons:
It's pot luck when it comes to mangers and jobs at the beginning.
The pay isn't really enough to live on for the first 2 year of the contract. Then the pay and conditions seen at manager level seem less than those in industry for the amount of work involved. Even if you wanted to stay on with the firm it would be an illogical choice.

The real career opportunities exist for people after they leave the firm.

headline: Think really hard before applying
pros:
- amazing peers from all over the world
- nice physical office space
cons:
- working 16 hours a day 7 days a week all year round like a slave, no appreciation
- poor pay compared to other audit firms
- lazy managers who leave seniors to do everything hence being overworked
- partners/directors placing all blame/expectation on seniors and do not reprimand managers.
- biased performance rating, basically if they do not like you they will not rate you well and they will not promote you. It is even worse when you are a minority race i.e Asian, black, etc.
- the so-called vacation policy MyTime is not bottomless. There is a maximum limit of 4, weeks which is in summer like every other Company so nothing special about it and does not make for all the overtime hours worked.

headline: Sweatshop with failed leadership
