If you like the idea of 80 hour weeks with 5 percent bonus and 5 percent raise and 3 years at each grade because your partner doesn't know anything about management consulting -  you've come to the right place!

headline: Good place to start your career

The work life balance can be brutal, especially during busy season.  
The work can be repetitive and boring.
Some of the seniors you will work for are not too bright.

headline: Great place to learn!
pros:
- Best financial service practices compared to other Big 4.
- Definitely a great place to learn for a fresh graduate accountant.
- Good salaries compared to other big 4 (since overtime is included).
- Work life balance is definitely better than the other big 4.
- Got to meet some marvelously smart and exemplary Bosses with whom you learn more than just accounting and auditing.
- As the slogan said "Cutting through complexity", the techniques applied for several industries is more straightforward and get to the point, with substantially less complexity compared to other big 4 (yes, I often compare our techniques with other big 4).
cons:
- The poorest medical benefit system compared to other big 4.
- A lot of people there just can't mind their own business and love to talk about the others, mostly the people talked bad in the back, gave harsh comments, and laughed at juniors for their newbie mistakes which in most cases, those mistakes are actually acceptable.
- Somehow it seems that even to the upper levels, personal feelings are still being considered as priority compared to the professional work ethics, which definitely slowing the works and trampling the professional concept.

- respected on my CV
cons:
- sometimes the hours are long considering the pay we get as trainees but this is offset with the experience and strength of your CV for future
- big firm = fair amount of bureaucracy which can be frustrating but goes with the territory tbh
- You have got to know what you want, why you want it, and make sure the right people know it. If you don't push for what you want you wont get it - simple. 
- No one cares about your career progression like you do so take responsibility for it, get on to the right jobs ASAP and build your reputation.

headline: KPMG is great
pros: Career progression and brand name are the two reasons why I decided to join KPMG.  They really know how to treat their employees well.  The Houston office has bought Cirque du Soleil tickets for everyone in the office, and they have rented a yacht to have a party on.  In the tax department during busy season, there is always free food, and they buy dinner for you ever night.  The benefits are top notch as well.  I think it is the only company that gives you five weeks vacation starting off.
cons: It is very structured.  Your career progression is not really based on performance.

cons:
-Long hours, bad work life balance, managers expect you to stay in the office until late even if you have nothing to do, the compensation is ridicolous compared to the hours of work;

headline: Tax Manager

headline: No Career Growth or Future - KPMG GSOC Noida
pros:
You will be getting free cabs [Not shared ones]

Best place to learn how to survive the most toxic environment.
cons:
Excessive micromanagement. 

You will have to justify every single second of your day and even if there is no such work, you will be asked to generate work by yourself.

No recognition to hard-working and skilled employees. Awards and appreciations are for favorites only.

Too much politics on all levels of management.

There is only Data entry work in the name of Cyber Security. If you're coming here for learning new things, you're going to regret the whole time.

You will be forced to work on your off days too and will be questioned for taking sick leaves.

The management here believes in QUANTITY but not Quality.

From Analyst to Shift Lead, everyone has the exact same responsibility i.e Data Entry work. Payout is the only difference here.

Management does not trust their employees.

Very unprofessional and bossy people leading the teams who don't know how to behave with their fellow colleagues.

Management doesn't value the feedback from their employees and nothing is going to change here.

headline: Not a good place for career growth
pros: Good work life balance, Good office, cafeteria, cab, health insuramce
cons: No career growth, lots of politics.

headline: Lack of HR
pros: Interesting work, you get the chance to meet different people from all over the world, doing many different types of work and from diverse companies. Great professional team in country and abroad. Diverse cases and situations help ypu to deepen your technical skills. Nice offices.
cons: The lack of clarity about the goals an employee should achieve in order to get a promotion, or to comply with the objectives of his current position. Requirements such as professional degree or english full proficiency are mandatory but sistematicaly overlooked in some cases, with no reason said. The employee needs to have everything in writing and signed to assure the agreements reached will be complied. There is no peer or subordinate evaluation. Coaching is null. Goal settings are only filled in order to comply formally with the firm global policies, but not taken seriously. Maternity leaves, sick leaves and vacations are rarely respected as employees usually work during such periods, a practice celebrated by the bosses. Training is promised but not complied, then demanded for promotions.

headline: Culture of Sexual Harassment
pros: It’s a recognizable name on your resume- but be aware it comes a cost and there are 100s of other companies that can serve this purpose, many of them with better reputations, and can provide more positive working experiences
cons: There is a rampant and unchecked culture of sexual harassment. You will find whispers of it everywhere- even here on Glassdoor. It was a promotion year for me, and my direct manager refused to meet with me unless I went to his hotel for my mid-year review. He wouldn’t give me feedback any other way, and he had pushed the meeting off for so long I was in danger of not making the deadline for feedback, so I went. Once I’m there, he actively avoids talking about work, instead telling me how much he likes me. He then tries to kiss me. I was shocked. I somehow get out of there. Then 2 weeks later, he kicks me off my project with no warning. The client is shocked. Not only does it disrupt the work, but there is no suitable replacement. My boss blames all of it on me to the Partners. He continues to retaliate against me. I have no idea what to do. I confide that something is wrong to one of the Partners, but I’m advised not to go to HR b/c that will only make things worse. But I realize I have to go HR and report him. HR does nothing. They take his side and never provide me with any details on how they conducted their investigation. They never provide me with a written document confirming the investigation. This was my #MeToo moment. I cried everyday for months, during and after. They promoted him to junior Partner. They fired me. This is a terrible place to work. Upper managers do whatever they want and no one stops them. There are multiple things written about KPMG and their toxic culture. When I met with employment attorneys and told them I worked at KPMG, they all gave indications that they already knew what I was going to say. Because they had heard it before. Because KPMG had done it before. And KPMG has continued to do it. Do not work here. It is not worth it.

headline: KPMG - Good name, not good treatment of staff
pros: KPMG offers attractive entry-level compensation packages and up until this year, great training. It is also an attractive big-4 name to have on a resume in the future.
cons:
This year, all nationwide training programs for Advisory were eliminated in favor of web-based to save money (immediately after being named #1 in training... something tells me that ranking isn't going to stick). 

The layoff procedure is not based on performance at all. Employees with positive feedback were laid off with no notice, while other employees with equal chargeability were not. There does not seem to be a method to the layoffs. 

Partners and upper managers have little to no interaction with staff. Staff right out of school in my group are treated as inferior due to lack of experience. They hired those individuals straight from school knowing they had only internship experience.

headline: KPMG is a great place to work, with good self promotion
pros: Decent salary, really cool projects opportunities to work for some really cool companies.  Great opportunity to travel as well as take overseas assignments.
cons: Bonus structure is not completely fair.  Amount of bonus' are not very high, as they mainly support your business case on your utilization without considering other factors such as training, client support with non-billable hours as well as internal team development.  Since these are not majorly considered, when you are working to make your team and kpmg a better company/performer, it does not reflect in your reviews/bonus, it may even be looked upon negatively by upper management as they are not informed in what you have accomplished for the teams internally.

headline: I learned a lot over the term of my career at KPMG, but it became stagnant.
pros: Annual management seminar for all of US tax; paid CPE opportunities; pension plan; a lot of client face time; great intranet site
cons: Inconsistency among offices; extra hours are expected; live to work mentality; poor annual bonuses; poor annual review process; imbalanced pay for similar roles

headline: KPMG GDC Audit Associate
pros: Good infrastructure, nice campus, cafeteria. Work wise nothing
cons: I worked with KPMG gdc for 3 years. January to March is busy season they make you work at least 13 hours a day. No importance to imployees they make people work like slaves. Approval of leaves is totally depend on TL. Manager has no say in anything manager is nothing but a toy. Everything is managed by director. TL is just like a normal associate. You make a mistake they treat you like a traitor. You won't learn anything with GDC just copy paste work. If you use your brain in your work manager is the 1st one to ask questions. You do as you told anything extra will fetch you an error and impact your performance.

headline: Honest review
pros:
Good work life balance than other big 4s
Good learning opportunity & good exposure
cons:
Lot of office politics
It’s all a matter of perception. If you are perceived as good by your manager, you can submit a poem in the name of a report and he will be happy. 
However, if you are not perceived as good but are very hard working and intelligent, whatever brilliant output you produce, your manager will always grade you badly in the performance cycle

headline: A great learning experience.
pros: Lots of professional development and opportunities to learn are provided.  The career paths are well defined.  There is very little conflicts or drama within the firm's staff.  The networking opportunities are excellent.
cons: Although not specific to the firm but the busy season (working about 50-60 hours per week plus commute) every year (approx Jan - Apr) can really take its toll on personal relationships and your health.  Bonuses are not as high in industry.  Recording time in 6 minute increments to bill to client's can be annoying.  Almost certainly need to "eat time" to be a top performer (ex. only bill 30 hours when you really worked 35).  Moves around certain stat holidays to other times of the year means no long weekends for sometimes three months.

headline: Not perfect, but best place I've ever worked
pros: Great people, collegial atmosphere most of the time, decent benefits, generous time off, strong values and good leadership in most parts of the firm.
cons: There are plenty of partners and leaders who do NOT live up to KPMG's values, which are heavily and consistently talked about  and promoted throughout the firm. Certain individuals are allowed to continue to mistreat and/or abuse more junior staff members simply because they're "rainmakers" and the firm wouldn't want to cut them loose. Also, the gender discrimination issue is still very much a thing. This year's promotions "process" demonstrated that very clearly. It's pretty frustrating to see female colleagues working their tails off and taking on extra workload, only to not get promoted, because a few men have been "in line" longer. That's not supposed to be what promotions are based on (according to every HR presentation I've ever seen on this topic), yet that's how it went down this year. Very frustrating.

headline: Looks good on a resume, but unsatisfying.
pros: Having Big 4 work experience on your resume. Learning about how a Big  4 firm operates. Gaining the experience of working with people all over the world on one project. Immediately being assigned to very difficult research projects.
cons: Not being able to gain an understanding of the entire audit and tax process. Too much bureaucracy and inefficiencies. Having too many managers to answer to. Some days I would have four managers want me to work on their projects and other days I would be out of work. Also, the performance evaluation process was poor. I think this goes back to having too many managers. Sure, everyone has a performance manager, but I was never placed on one assignment with this manager. How is someone supposed to evaluate you, if they've never worked with you? Lastly, I was interested in gaining the NY experience requirements towards the CPA designation because I had already passed the exam, but was not once assigned the audit work that's required.

headline: A resume builder and little more
pros: KPMG is a resume builder for future jobs. Additionally, if you see your life goal as becoming a partner and securing that massive salary while completely detaching yourself from your family and friends then it is a great place to build a monitarily wealthy career 10 - 15 years down the line.
cons: KPMG spends significant time promoting its brand and selling itself as one of the greatest employers to work for. While benefits are good, they are coupled with and rather negated by low salaries (considering the time and knowledge commitment required to perform the job) and very long hours. 5 weeks PTO is somewhat negated by the massive overtime commitment. With large jobs the firm is frequently successful in billing for its employees’ overtime and all such billings largely go into the Partners’ pockets.  KPMG very sneakily appeals most effectively to its core demographic, i.e. recent college graduates (typically 26 and under). As part of this core demographic we are treated as the minions of the firm and are drawn in through the firm making use of such techniques as plying us with alcohol and bringing us in as a cohesive "starting class" in order that we feel a certain bond with our peers and thus feel guilty about saying a bad word about the firm.

headline: Very broad experience in accounting, auditing, process and financial modelling
pros:
1. One of the best places to start career.
2. A lot of talanted and bright people. Wide network of contacts.
3. Interesting projects and tasks.
4. There is a chance to communicate with senior corporate managers (clients) and told them you opinion on the current issues.
cons:
1. Low level of salaries. 
2. Sometimes "commitment" to the project means only sitting near the senoir or manager late in the night, but not the constructive work, which could be done in the moning at the working time. So the work/life balance problem.
3. Sometimes bad planning. You can do nothing all working day, but at 17 00 you can receive a massive block of work, which should be done "urgently" till tomorrow morning. Very often that urgent work become unnecessary. So the same work/life balance problem caused by unprofessional project manager.
4. Small project budgets which will lead to  decrease in project team and increase in workload of team members.

headline: Management Consulting:  Highly Siloed
pros: Good training and benefits; Offices in most large cities.
cons: (1) Comp metrics and review process relies on the same few metrics for all consultants across the entire firm--which is a strength and a weakness. If your team is a strong one great. If you are joining to build up or to turnaround a practice, the metrics are applied inflexibly. (2) Cultural and metrics-caused silos creating disincentives to work with consultants outside your own partner's team. This can effect the quality of the work if the best resources are not located within your partner's work team (3) compliance rules necessitated by the company's audit practice effectively mean you can't consult to about 1/5 of the Fortune 1000 economy that use the company's audit practice and you and your spouse will be continually monitored with respect to what you invest in, where you bank, etc etc. For those starting out, this is not much of an issue. For those experienced hires with a complex investment portfolio, and who have a set of prior business relationships they want to market to, be aware. Culture, metrics, and compliance challenges are typical of other big four firms, but for experienced hires coming from non-big four professional service firms, the adjustment is material. (4) When selling new work the race to apportion "sales credit" metrics among the participants is a contact sport. (5) Firm worldwide organizational makeup is a hindrance to winning multi country consulting engagements. Ask your hiring partner to describe the "worldwide organization" and how it works together or the percentage of his team's revenue that depends on cross boarder engagements.

headline: Titanic heading to the iceberg
pros:
Nothing, not even the fact that  it's a big 4 because when this fact hasn't benefited me yet, it's not really a "pro" Most accountants want to have "big 4" on their resume but until I am getting the alleged advantage of having that on my resume, I can't say there is a "pro" with this firm at the moment.

Interestingly, when I tell people I work at KPMG, many of them don't even know what it is because I guess only "accountants" know KPMG.
cons:
Too many to name... Cumbersome and non-performing IT is one of the many huge problems.

There are so many bad things about this firm that in my opinion, there should only the Big 3....because this firm should just go away like Arthur Anderson.

headline: Great People and learning experience
pros: That's just it, I've really enjoyed working with the people at KPMG and have learned so much and probably would stay longer if the compensation matched the experience.
cons:
When I learned how severely underpaid I am while working 80+ hours as a senior associate, I've decided the Company is not for me.

Just to give some background - I have a masters, CPA, worked on a large public filer for the last 2.5 years, worked many overtime hours and my compensation was 66K salary with no Bonus.

headline: Positive epiphanies from a very negative experience

cons:
- Lack of transparency in company processes and policies.
- Blatant cannibalization of chargeability/chargeable hours by management, which the head office/HR does not seem to grasp.
- More respect will be given to you if you are an all out "yes man" instead of a genuine thinker. 
- Lack of a support staff, new joiners are expected to be administrative "peons."
- All support functions like IT, finance and admin do not seem to realize that we are all on the same side.

headline: Audit Analyst
pros:
1.)Exposure to high ranking client personnel, including executives
2.)Prestigious name to have on your CV
3.)Work with specialists and practitioners
4.)It is easy to get a promotion
5.)Resources,Constant Training,Subscriptions and research tools,Holidays
cons:
The actual work** - especially in the audit division. You'll be given sections of the balance sheet to investigate and obtain evidence supporting the numbers. Then you'll make photocopies and tie in all of the numbers back to the balance sheet. These numbers have to be referenced on both the balance sheet and evidence and then filed. This process is repeated on every client, and can be boring and repetitive. You'll be doing this for the first three years.
2.)Hours**. One of the arguments for the lower salary than those in investment banking can expect is that you are working fewer hours than someone, in say, M&A. However, it's not always the case. During "busy season" (January - April) you can expect to work from 9am to 8pm, and the occasional weekend. If you are booked on continuous year-end audits, you'll work 9am until 7pm or 8pm every night. Each audit has a deadline, and it is essential that it is met to avoid fines and make sure the client stays happy. This means that you will work whatever hours are needed to make that deadline.
3.)Hierarchy**. The organisational structure is very hierarchical and rigid. At the bottom are the first, second and third year associates, then the executives, assistant managers, managers, senior managers and partners. If you are highly regarded it will take you around 14 years to get to partner level. However, out of an intake of many hundred, only a handful will ever get there.

headline: Good benefits but fragmented business model

cons:
- Significant lack of technical rigor, even at the top
- KPMG claims to be moving to a national business model but Partners or MDs in different regions claw at each other for the same work (e.g., due to prior client relationships)
- Management includes some of the worst I've seen... Toxic Partners and MDs are kept around for their ability to sell work, not their ability to effectively manage a team while developing strong employees
- Forget about a work/life balance unless you're in an administrative or business support role (at least, if you want to move up in a timely manner and be respected)

headline: If you love auditing, you'll love KPMG...
pros:
Great people. Coworkers are (almost) always smart, interesting, fun and your (large) peer group is composed of people your age (with whom you likely share some common interests). 

Sexes up your resume. If you want a career in finance/accounting this is the place to start. A breeding ground for controllers. 

The partner/manager group is composed of good (actually pretty great) people who take time to know each member of their teams individually. 

Best Big 4 firm in Seattle.
cons:
The pay structure could be improved (pay relative to cost of living not 'market'). All your hard work gets the partners (not necessarily you) paid. 

While top talent is identified though a fair ratings process, it is subsequently exploited. In other words, if you get a high rating you will be subjected to a challenging, (i.e. crushing) workload because "you can handle it.' This is fine if you love auditing. However, if you don't take satisfaction from being treated like a cop by clients who don't respect you, then auditing may not be for you.

Also, KPMG's technology lags behind the other Big 4 firms and, at times, is borderline mind-numbing.

headline: Part-time Experience at KPMG ITA in Munich
pros: Multi-cultural work force, communication is easy between colleagues as well as with leaders. Working in a leading accounting firm like KPMG provides one quick access to large pool of resources and up to date info if one really want to develope himself in fields like tax, accounting and accounting-related advisory. Besides, KPMG has an especially strong presence in Germany, compared to other countries, and after the merger with KPMG UK, the future of the company seems to be quite bright.
cons: The company is big, so inevitably sometimes a bit chaotic in terms of employee training, performance review etc. Get use to that and you will be just fine. Small interest groups can be found in each department. And last but not least, the work there is not very exciting, most time just routine work, even in the advisory department.

headline: Exploitation
pros:
You can learn a lot about how businesses work.

You find out fast how hard life can be in the finance sector, so you can better prepare for the future.
cons: Fierce competition and exploitation. Big4 business model is based on exploitation although they would not recognize this officially but the management knows it and the money flows to the top. You are expected to constantly deliver and do over-time. It is good as a start because you see how tough the life can be. Many people get burned out quickly and there is a very high personnel turnover. This means also lower quality in deliverables. Do not get fouled by the marketing. Try it if you start your career, otherwise I would not suggest it unless you want to become a slave.

headline: Toxic Beyond Anything Imaginable
pros: Vacation time, +twice a year closure for a week in the summer, and again at the holidays. But you'll have to make up the hours you take off in the same month, or be reprimanded for not hitting your utilization and impact score.
cons: Insane hours, 12, 13, 14, 15hr days, and then  you have enter your billable hours everyday, adding another 30-60min everyday. Twelve different managers you report to, all for a different process, and rarely the one you work on. Each one giving their own feedback to your manager. The absolute worst of all companies I've worked for. Senior leadership is toxic, and it filters down to everything under them. Limited promotion opportunities coupled with the culture create an environment of corporate psychopaths, all bucking for that promotion and throwing everyone under the bus and pointing fingers in an attempt to climb the ladder. But the only ones who get promoted are the ones who get brought up from intern level by the director, and/or brown nose to no end to become their favorite understudy. I've watched them overwork and chase out countless individuals, all based on sex, bigotry, and racism. They play the inclusive card and advertise it to no end, put it's all for marketing value.

headline: KPMG China = False Advertising
pros: Fabulous co-workers who for the most part are polite, professional, and intelligent.  Depending on what field you are in, the company brand is well perceived. If you are in IT or technology stay away.  The work itself is fairly easy but tedious and futile. Most people in Advisory just make PowerPoint slides or fetch coffee for Partners and Directors.
cons:
Very disorganized, low pay, and long hours. The Directors there are for the most part incompetent.  The mandatory training is unstructured and continuous.  They will also move most of the current employees to a new building in Wong Chuk Hang on the South Horizons line. So don't expect to work in the Prince's or Hysan Place buildings for long.

One Director who joined after I did said to me, "I think I made a big mistake joining KPMG." I laughed and said, "That's the same thing I told my wife." 50% of new joiners leave within a year. Not because it's difficult but because you are assigned work that has nothing to do with your area of expertise or what was described in the advertised job description.

headline: Intern
pros: Work life balance, interesting work, very diversified
cons: Low salary as an intern compared to other corporate finance interns

headline: There is a reason why it a "great place to LAUNCH your career."  Don't stay to long!!
pros: If you work hard and demostrate competence at your job you will be promoted to at least senior associate, things get a little more politcal at the manager level.  You will have an opportunity to work on multiple engagments (depending on the office) and with many different people.  The job will challange you and you develop accounting/auditing skills very quickly.  Partners and senior management have been around along time and are usually well connected in the community and they are good people to know and leverage from.  The benefits are good, some of the best in the Big 4.  You get 25 days of vacation and I have never had any trouble getting time off.
cons: The hours during busy season are brutal but probably not any different than the other firms.  KPMG technology seems to lag behind the other firms and our methodology can be redundant at times.  Employee ratings can be political and are often not based on performance (i.e. hours worked, deadlines met, professional credentials earned).  There is little chance of being promoted outside of the normal process (2 years Senior Associate, 5 years Manager, 7 year Senior Manager, 10+ Partner)

headline: A good training experience, but not the career for most
pros:
Training was good on an overall level, such as for the Tax code and concepts.  Having the firm's name on your resume is absolutely required by some companies in and outside the industry for employment at higher, more senior levels.  

Management has a very high technical competency.  Promotion is based almost exclusively on that particular factor (note mention of this in the "Con" section as well).

The number and level of benefits is high, as is generally common for the industry.
cons:
Training on basic applications, such as proprietary software, and industry-standard software used by the firm was essentially non-existent.  Managers generally have little or no interest in training new staff; the general attitude seems to be "sink or swim."  

As noted in the "Pros" section, management is very technically competent.  Unfortunately, this is virtually the only factor considered or valued.  People skills, training skills, and basic general management skills are, at best, considered irrelevant; at worst, they are looked down upon. Due to the nature of the industry and the personality types which are most suited to the work (especially compliance work), it is quite unusual to have both the necessary technical competence and people skills in the same package.  Criticisms of work performance are frequently presented in hyperbolic terms, and can be startlingly personal in nature:  "careless", "sloppy", etc., are frequently and casually thrown around even when there are a small number of insignificant errors.   

Accounting firms, especially Big Four firms, are known for a "churn and burn" culture:  departures are frequent and tenures are not normally more than a few years.  Due to a steady influx of young (and naive) students, there is very little impetus for change in the work culture.  As an example, KPMG just recently allowed employees to begin wearing jeans on "casual Friday", more than a few years behind the curve.

headline: Advisory - Risk Consulting
pros: As a consulting firm, you get to work on more than one project compared with industry where the focus is the one job you hold. The variety of projects may be hit or a miss depending on the skillset and how well reputed your MD/Partner is. This can be an excellent place to start off a career straight out of school and/or if you have no liability outside of work (family, hobbies etc.)
cons:
- Fairly long working hours (70 + hours a week) is a consistency.
- Weekends are almost always tied up with work that cannot be completed through the week. 
-Work-life balance is a lip service. It also depends on who your partner/MD is - some appreciate work life balance more than others.
- There is little transparency in how the promotion process works - it almost always feels that people (MD/Partners) are gaming the system to their benefit, so unless you're cosy with your boss, it wouldn't matter how effective your client delivery and number of hours worked through the year is.
-Compensation at the year end is a one way street - no negotiation
- There is an underlying notion that you must be in a role for 2 years before being considered for a promotion, despite a stellar pre-KPMG resume. Lesson learn't - negotiate your title before you join the firm. 
- Cross functional rotation is almost non-existent unless you pitch for it yourself and your line of management is supportive of it. This is in contrast with how the firm itself touts the flexibility it offers in terms of performance development by allowing folks to develop cross-functional skills.
- Some folks are offered roles they are not suited/qualified for e.g. a 6 year stint in the firm can lead you into a Director role straight out of school, while many others despite more qualified experience and equally good qualifications may languish due to incompetent management/lack of objective recognition.

headline: Manager, IT Technical Lead
pros:
Great Company, People, benefits, & values!


They live up to their core values:
We lead by example - at all levels acting in a way that exemplifies what we expect of each other and our member firms’ clients.
We work together - bringing out the best in each other and creating strong and successful working relationships.
We respect the individual - respecting people for who they are and for their knowledge, skills, and experience as individuals and team members.
We seek the facts and provide insight - challenging assumptions, pursuing facts, and strengthening our reputation as trusted and objective business advisers.
We are open and honest in our communication - sharing information, insight, and advice frequently and constructively, and managing tough situations with courage and candor.
We are committed to our communities - acting as responsible corporate citizens, and broadening our skills, experience, and perspectives through work in our communities.
Above all, we act with integrity - complying with all applicable laws and regulations, upholding the highest professional standards, providing sound advice, and rigorously maintaining our independence.
cons:
No work/life balance.

That being said I am not sure that there are too many companies in today's work environment that can offer that.

headline: Partners are kings -- if you accept that, than you are fine, otherwise you have a serious problem.
pros: The salary is competetive, that is a plus, and if you manage to get out in time with good references, this might be helpful for your future career outside the firm.
cons: As mentioned, partners are above everyone, and if you show them their respect (no matter if they are right or wrong), you might have a fair chance to progress. But don't even try to challenge the processes or their opinions, as this will seriously hurt you and your career. Also, the company is extremely political, which affects everyone, the teams and also some partners who have not positioned themselves well.

headline: KPMG UK - Financial Services Consultant - Positive experiences despite lack of direction
pros: If through a mixture of luck and judgement you can get yourself onto an interesting client project with colleagues who will support you, there are plenty of positive experiences to be had. You can take on responsibility early, engage with very senior people at the client, be involved in big decisions and learn a lot about the marketplace; whether in a specific sub-sector of the financial services industry, or more broadly if you can network your way onto projects for other teams within KPMG. There is a nice mix of career-consultants and people with deep industry experience, so you can learn from both sides. If you like drinking and international travel, you will be well catered for as a consultant at KPMG.
cons:
The lack of strategic direction means that you can be working on very different projects from year to year, and month to month. For a while this is a pro, as it lets you try different approaches, learn to apply consulting skills in a variety of contexts, but in the long run, it is a con for me, as it makes career planning difficult. KPMG ultimately will do whatever clients are paying for this particular month: regulation, IT implementation, business strategy, tax reclaims, or a bums-on-seats job where you are no different to a one-man-band contractor.
Where will I be working in 3 months time? As a consultant, you never really know. 5 days a week in Brussels? 4 days a week in Dublin? 11 hour days plus weekend work in London? Or a more relaxing time "on the bench", working on whatever random client pitch absolutely must be finished and submitted in the next 2 hours, when nobody can agree on what our opinions, approach or prices are. Some people thrive on this environment, but generally not the ones with kids.
Performance management, mentoring and coaching of junior colleagues gets some support and a bit of lip-service, but ultimately it's sink or swim, from manager grade downwards.

headline: Great Exposure

pros:
It's all depends on the team, when are you assigned to a team with a good senior or a  manager, your life will be much easier. Otherwise, your everyday life in KPMG is miserable. 
The firm offers a lot of trainings which if you want to learn, you can always improve yourself. However, when you get off from work 2am in the morning, most of time you are exhausted. 
25 days PTO is definitely a big bonus.
cons: Too much bureaucracy in the firm. They say your PML is supposed to be your side, unfortunately, I didn't feel the support at all.

job_title: Tax Associate, State and Local Tax
headline: Great Place To Work! (Atlanta Office)
pros:
- Decent Starting Salary
- Excellent Benefits
- Attentive Management
- Good training Opportunities
- Low-No Travel

Over and again I read how others are dissatisfied with Big 4 accounting jobs due to the number of hours required and the work/life balance. If you think a work week should be 40 hours and that you should be compensated at a higher rate of pay for 'overtime', you'll find KPMG 'demanding'. The fact is that if you are looking for a 40 hour/week job, join a union and become an employee in a different industry. Better yet, come and work for KPMG and start complaining about the hours - it'll make me look good.

Read a little about successful people and their workloads when they were young. 40 hours/week? Whatever. Personally, I don't blink at a 50-60 hour work week. After all, there are 168 hours in a week. If I work 60, travel another 3 hours to and from work, and sleep 56 hours, that leaves me 49 hours/week for personal time, or 7 hours per day. That's more than enough time for me to have a strong social life.
cons:
- Unclear about bonus/raise structure. Management should make an effort to keep employees informed re: expected departmental bonuses and raises.
- While "career paths" are fine, dedicated individuals who are carrying the load 'a rank higher' should be duly noted and promoted.

pros: Good work culture. Employee friendly.

headline: Not for everyone
pros:
- Good management
- Flexible work arrangements
- Great opportunities to develop as a professional, especially for someone entering the industry. Better than doing an MBA as working at KPMG provides you with a broad overview of the big businesses and public sector in Australia.
cons:
- No specialisation tracks, chaotic work assignment that is irrelevant to your skillset
- "Bench shaming": If you are not assigned to client billable work, it's your fault, regardless of whether there is enough work. Partners and Directors should be accountable for not bringing in enough work, not the delivery staff.
- Due to short-term engagements, you will hardly ever do anything stimulating. The engagement is over just when things start to get interesting. Doing anything useful carries risk and commitment, and KPMG is a very risk averse organisation.

headline: Audit Assistant
pros: Friendly working environment, many big clients, interesting projects, good training schemes, centrally located, fast pace environment which suits the young graduates
cons: I was in audit which means we have to deal with extremely tight deadlines in peaked reasons. The job involves a lot of travel, somtimes to undesirable locations and to many factories. One is expected to get up early to be ready for a factory trip and after spending a long day working there, return home to find herself/himself staying up late to finish the job to meet the tight deadlines and then get up very early again. It was a stressful tiring job.

headline: Don't get confused with KPMG India and KPMG Global Services
pros: The firm KGS is a joint venture between KPMG UK, KPMG US and KPMG India. The support hub headquarted at Gurgaon provides services to the member firms.(Operations are in Bangalore too). The benefit of working with KGS is the global exposure (only if you are part of a client facing team).
cons:
1. Ever-changing management, bureaucracy 
2. Frequent lay off of processes/teams
3 .Disparity between KPMG and KGS employees
4. Low compensation to KGS employees

pros: MOst of the people are great at KPMG (obviously a few do get through who you wouldn't socialise with if they didn't work with you).  So many of the senior staff are approachable which always helps.
cons:
The hours are ALWAYS long especially once you get into years 3 and beyond.  It's always "busy season".  The appraisal process is flawed and everyone is always moaning about it; unfortunately it's more of a popularity contest than how good the person is, which inevitably causes some of the best people to leave the firm.

The salary and bonus is rubbish when compared to bankers/lawyers of a similar intellect!

cons:
-Data literacy and capabilities is well behind the times, especially in certain silos. 
-Limited in early career data roles. Overall, I would not call it a mature data company. They are trying, but the adoption seems to be moving slowly.
-Too much focus at individual level on utilization rates

headline: KPMG pretty good place to work.
pros: brand name, competitive pay, great networking opportunities, great onsite and out of state trainings, generous expense policy, many opportunities to explore different areas of accounting and finance, flexible, rotational opportunities availalbe.  this is a big 4 accounting firm and is well respected not only in the accounting industry but in consulting, banking, and industry.  experience here will open up many doors.
cons: direct managers do not have good management experience.  in order to succeed you need to become friends with multiple managers and get on going feedback.  it might be hard to utilize all the resourses that could be available to you.  hours can be long but in general are pretty reasonable.

headline: Great Company, Awful Politics
pros: KPMG defends its brand and prestige vigorously, so they do everything possible to hire and retain the best people. This means great benefits, competitive pay, caring about work/life balance, and plenty of flexibility in ones schedule and choice of work location. These come with high expectations and long hours, however.
cons: Very little upward mobility unless you luck out in the politics game, adopt the 1900's hierarchy, and develop a robust vocabulary of buzzwords and cliches. As a partnership, there is also an unclear leadership structure and a glaring lack of salespeople.

headline: Interesting challenging work, little work-life balance
pros:
- Opportunity to work on interesting, big scale projects
- Work with the brightest specialists in their fields
- Opportunity to lead early in your career. In audit you can start supervising teams from your 2nd year.
- Usually more paid time off than what's offered by the industry + paid study leaves (2 weeks per year for those taking ACCA exams) + paid/unpaid time off for overtime worked (depends on the country though)
- Great exit opportunities - many companies respect and look for Big4 experience
- Hard work is recognized and rewarded
- Many opportunities for development outside of accounting - can ask for delivering client/inter-company trainings, presentations, etc.
cons:
- Busy season can be stressful - long hours, weekends, last minute are expected
- Hard (or more likely - almost impossible) take a vacation during busy season - no skiing trips in February :( 
- Travel can be up to 70-80% during the busy season
- High turnover among assistants/supervisors leading to projects being often understaffed

headline: KPMG a place where success is not rewarded.
pros: I enjoy working at KPMG because the people for the most part are very competent.  The hours you work while numerous are flexible.  If I want to be here until two in the morning one night so I can leave at four the following day nobody questions it.  It's truly a matter of getting the job finished and finished well rather then simply being here because other people are.
cons:
The number one downside of working at KPMG is that promotions are in no way shape or form based on merit and are in large part due to tenure.  I am currently stuck working on a project that I am leading because my senior associate is incompetent but because she has been here longer is above me on the chain of command I technically report to her and she receives the positive recognition.  

The other major downside to working at KPMG is you should never and I mean never ever calculate your hourly rate because you'll want to shoot yourself.

headline: Lots of responsibility, motivated co-workers, financial rewards
pros:
Working at KPMG was one of the best career moves I ever made. I was given lots of responsibility on projects, I worked with ambitious and educated co-workers, and I was rewarded financially at year-end for all the extra hours I worked late night and on weekends.

I would highly recommend a position at this firm for those just entering the workforce upon graduating college.
cons: While my efforts were recognized and rewarded, if you want to work with another manager or partner, you need to speak up, politely.

headline: Great place to begin, bad place to end...
pros: KPMG is a great place to develop into a professional and generate tremendous insights into how the corporate world operates. No project is the same and being associated with the KPMG brand can open a lot of doors. You are given a lot of freedom to drive your own initiatives, rewarded for taking part in external and internal events, and encouraged to develop new business opportunities.
cons:
It is an extremely political environment at times where promotion seems more strongly linked to your relationships than your ability, while individual partners often carve out their own little fiefdom complete with fawning courtiers beholden to them. Pay is also terrible when you factor in the hours you have to put in, particularly at the graduate and assistant manager level. And like Amway and Avon, the big pay day only comes when you make it to equity partner--which you can expect to happen around 6 to 10 years after you make partner!  

Lastly, the partnership at the top at times feels like a boy's club and so you often feel excluded as a woman.

headline: Be careful what you wish for.....
pros: You are surrounded by bright people and there is a lot of opportunity to learn about different clients, industries, issues, and opportunities. The environment ,while sometimes cliquie, offers a lot of camaraderie. The benefits are decent and the vacation time is generous.
cons: The hours are long - not because they need to be to get the work done, but because utilization and face time are important. The "Employer of Choice" is a marketing tool, but poorly put into play. You can voice your opinion regarding what projects you would or would not like to work on but in the end you will just be placed where they want you to be - regardless of where you live. Depending on management you are working with, you may get haggled about justified expenses (e.g. train fare or mileage and tolls). Vacations are expected to be flexible (you may be asked to cancel or postpone). Promotions are far and few between depending on which group you work in.

headline: Senior Associate
pros: The most positive aspect of KPMG is the exposure it provides: Exposure to great clients, exposure to a multitude of responsibilities, and exposure to different environments that gives you the confidence to succeed wherever you go. No matter how stressful some days were, I will forever be thankful to KPMG for the skills that it taught me.
cons: KPMG management understands that it's a high prestige firm that attracts some very qualified individuals just by its name.  As a result, compensation is relatively low and work-life balance, depending on engagement, is practically non-existent. You often feel like you're an interchangeable cog of a large machine, which would usually be an accurate assessment of your role at the firm.  The times when you don't feel like an interchangeable cog are when you get worked dumped on you because management couldn't find more cogs to put next to you.  401k match improved when I was at the firm but was still average at the time I left.

headline: KPMG Pros & Cons
pros:
Working at KPMG allows you the opportunity to network with many individuals across numerous industries. In some cases, it's almost like a fraternity or sorority.  In addition, you are also able to experience the business issues faced across different organizations that help you gain a bigger picture about a specific problem.  Good Resume Builder.  

Also, working at KPMG offers you the flexibility that most industry jobs do not offer.  As a consultant, you are always on the go and reporting to different clients.  This means that you must really learn to manage your time effectively to meet your clients needs and also your personal time.  Given this understanding, management often allow you to work from home when necessary.  In addition, the vacation package is higher than most industry jobs.  

Job Security at Audit Firms are typically good.  Publically traded companies are mandated by the Government to be audited and therefore, there is a steady stream of work to be performed in this industry.
cons:
KPMG is operated under a Partnership.  As in all partnership, it appears that it is difficult to control the organization and steer it in one direction as a corporation would be able to.  Each regional office appears to have their own agenda, and the partners themselves do not always appear to be in-sync with the company direction.  It's oftenly appears like an "every man for themselves" type atmostphere... espeicially when the business environment is like the way it is these days.  

The pay at KPMG is sub-par compared to industry jobs, especially in the Southwest Region (TX, LA, CO, AR).  While the Oil & Gas sector has exploded, the pay at KPMG for similar type work has not been able to match what industry is paying.  It is not uncommon to hear people leaving KPMG for 20-30% salary increases.   

 Often, the notion of Work Life Balance is false.  It is not uncommon for Staff and Management to work 60 hour work weeks, especially during the year-end audit busy seasons.  Advisory management in the southwest often mandate 50 hour work weeks to their staff in order to meet year-end goals.  Managing this type of lifestyle is not always easy and is typically the reason why people leave for other jobs.

headline: Great place to launch career & grow professionally. Workload can be draining, overwhelming, and stressful.
pros: The salary is great for a first job (although other Big 4's offer more), great place to start your career and grow professionally, lots of training and professional development opportunity, 25 PTO days a year (however many times too busy to use all of it), people are generally friendly, learn a lot through on the job training and experience, technology and work supplies readily available, get to travel to new places (sometimes rural) for client visits and see the U.S. Learn about many different technologies as you're exposed to many different IT systems from various client engagements.
cons: Work/life balance is lacking especially during busy season. Typically 9-12 hour long days and not unusual for people to work on weekends. Mentor program needs improvement. Job can be very overwhelming and stressful especially during busy season. Very heavy client facing job and must build rapport and win over clients-lots of times they are wary of auditors presence and must build trust. IT helpdesk via phone is not always ideal for those who prefer in-person assistance when experiencing technology issues.

headline: Horrible people management
pros:
- Brand name, however tarnish by some recent scandals 
- Market pay, better than other 2nd tier accounting firms but slightly lower than the other big 3
- Good training 
- Reasonable working hour
cons:
- Jobs are gradually shifting back to the Mainland offices. Since those partners and senior managers do not have much skills other than audit and the lack of business sense, they can go no where other than staying in the firm. The combined effect is that there is not as many opportunities as before for junior staffs to get to more senior level.

- People management staff is forever changing.  Every staff feels there is a pressure of downsizing from time to time. Staffs morale can not be lower.

- When I say horrible management system, I meant it is managed by people. Strong favoritism exists for some managers / senior mangers for job allocations. Some male managers book some other female staffs having other things in their mind other than simply work.

headline: Advisory Associate

headline: The Best Firm of the Big 4 Accounting Firms
pros: The base salary is the most competitive of all Big 4 firms. They also give you the most vacation days of any Big 4 firm. I believe most give around 16 days vacation, but KPMG gives around 25. Great Location on Park Avenue in New York City. Great culture, everyone is extremely friendly, not snobby and stuck up like other Big 4 firms I worked for. KPMG truly cares about their employees. If you ever have to choose between big 4 firms, I would definitely choose KPMG.
cons: Nothing except that you obviously work long hours.

headline: Audit Associate
pros:
Almost no hierarchy, can stop by a partner to discuss any issue
Helpful colleges 
No bonuses but a great overtime payment! You get paid for  every extra hour you work extra (full time working week 40 h, which rarely happens in auditors life). Payment depends what kind clients/engagement you have. If everything runs smoothly – no so much overtime money but less stressful environment.
cons:
Huge personnel turnover and always understaffed 
Even if they have good learning opportunities there is ongoing reduction in learning development /education (a lot of online courses now) 
No possibilities to get ACCA through KPMG
Stressful assignments due to low budget 
Promotion to Senior Associate after 2,5 years (meanwhile in other cities in Sweden after 2 years) 
Not competitive salary comparing to the marker. A month salary could be increase approx. 30% if starting position as  Business Controller at any other company in Sweden .

headline: Investigations
pros: Big company so always lots going on and interesting workstreams if you have the right contacts to get you onto the work.
cons: Long hours with little compensation, or time in lieu. Time off is always promised but seldom delivered on. Can be very cliquey and if not in the "in" crowd you will fid it difficult to get onto any decent workstreams and you will be stuck with the drudge. Like all big corporate top heavy and decision making can be divorced from the coalface.

headline: Not a professional company to work with
pros: Scope of learning is great
cons:
Many-
Concept of block leave is only on paper. In reality block leave is never given
Concept of year end review is again on paper. Your performance manager has already decided your rating at the beginning of the year and his decision won't change by year end
Bad pay master and bonus for the amount of work getting done

headline: Lots of resources and tools to build knowledge, excessive work and hours during busy season. Good place to launch career

cons: Pay (not horrible, but not good), lots of hours, large corporate office.

headline: Great resume builder but.......
pros: Great place to start a career for the young professionals and build a solid resume.  With the right mindset you can increase your knowledge/skills and broaden your exposure to the marketplace you wish to focus on.  Can also develope great contacts within the industry you practice.
cons: Very political and too much weighted on tenure versus skills/knowledge/accomplishments.  I have to question the career development for certain areas within the firm.  If you are not in the right circle of leaders and management it can be very hard to move up within the firm.  I expected smart intellegient people to work with when i came here however i was very unimpressed with the level of knowledge and skills from both the staff as well as managers and even certain partners.

headline: Good company, work environment, and benefits but small salary increases and limited career growth opportunities.
pros: KPMG has a good work atmosphere, friendly people, solid benefits, and they seem to care about creating an open and inclusive culture.  I'm able to work from home one day a week, sometimes more if needed, and I like the leadership team I report into.  I think KPMG cares about employees and tries very hard to take care of people.
cons: In my area, very limited growth opportunities.  I've been in my current position for over four years and because of team size I see no potential area for advancement.  Also, while my starting salary was very good, raises i general are meager.  In some ways, I feel as if I've lost ground from when I began at the firm.

headline: How it works...No Fluff Talk Here
pros: Career Advancement and Exposure to Clients/Industry
cons:
To start you are underpaid and overworked so you are always insecure about your pay until you make Sr. Manager (Assuming you can cut it in the Big 4 and didn't slip by the hiring filters).  After 1 to 2 years the work is not challenging and your career becomes tedious task management.  This task management steadily increases until you become Sr. Manager when you can delegate these tasks, concentrate more on the sale of work you may not be comfortable delivering, and manage frustrated staff from afar.  


If you do not have strong character and work hard enough to be kept around the following will happen: The longer you are around the more tainted you become with this whole selling the image theme and lose sight of actually delivering value internally and to clients.  Then if you stay around too long there is not a good exit strategy because the pay is higher than a job you can get in industry or consulting given your limited skillset.  So you are stuck with a limited skillset and praying for SOX 2.0 until that day comes when you make partner and have to live your new life under the microscope like a preacher or politician.

headline: Would not recommend if you want to realise your potential
pros: Lunch allowance, diverse experience, difficult to get fired
cons:
- Company has not been doing well in recent years, as partners who cannot meet target (for several years) are kept in their roles
- If you are unfortunate enough to fall into teams that are not doing well, you are likely to be resourced on to projects that have nothing to do with your role (advisory employees resourced on audit or tax) - in other words a waste of your expertise. 
- This also means that partners are likely to sell whatever they can, even in an area that they have no expertise in. This usually leads to under-resourcing and not being able to deliver a quality output as expected by the client. 
- interesting and stimulating projects are rare. For example in advisory, you are very likely to be resourced onto PMO roles formatting the same deck every week. 
- There has been a push for mental health initiatives but high pressure on utilisation and demanding project means that you are likely to not be able to attend any of those sessions. 
- Poor company performance translates into limited headcount. To get promoted, you have to be fortunate enough to be on a growing team and have connections.

headline: Exploitative, unbelievable working environment
pros: None. You will be exposed to clients who will offer you jobs if you have any qualifications.
cons: I was not paid my monthly salary for which I had to officially file a complaint against them. I was massively underpaid. You will work with the most incompetent people on the face of this earth. They should change the name of KPMG Lower Gulf to KPMG Little India because that's where everyone is from. A very unsafe environment for women to work at. Most of the women are there because they cant find any other jobs or accept harrasment as a way of life because they are coming from even worse countries and work environments. As soon as you'll enter the workplace itll feel like you are in a village in a third world country. Most of the people behave that way. They will do everything to misuse you and they obviously dont care about the flagship name as they refuse to pay your salary or feel obliged to follow the law. People have little to no qualifications and have a very street like mentality. I have no idea how does KPMG allow them to use their name amongst such disgraceful, inhuman and illiterate leadership.

headline: Frat boys that take themselves too seriously
pros:
KPMG is rapidly growing and outpacing the other Big 4 accounting firms in terms of employee satisfaction.  Because of the rapid growth, there is a very open dialogue between the Partners, MDs, managers and associates about where the firm/team has been and where it is going.  In a lot of ways, the environment within the advisory group is similar to that of a startup because people are constantly being hired, new clients are always being sought after and signed, and the group is experiencing double digit growth in terms of revenue and headcount. 

The work experience is top notch.  The clients and nature of the work you are exposed to is excellent, and your ability to make an impact on the final product is huge because deal teams are small (3-5 people).  You'll learn a lot if you are proactive enough.
cons: The downside of all the growth happening is that it is easy to fall between the cracks.  You really need to be proactive and look for your own work to be on by politicking with your peers, otherwise you won't get picked up on work.  The general composition of the group is 25 to 30-somethings that are all single and act like they're still in college.  The people in the San Francisco office in particular tend to take themselves too seriously and have a bit of an elitist attitude because the majority of the clients are private equity, and therefore they think that they are somehow working in private equity (they're not).    This is a well-documented fact amongst the group, as you can often hear other surrounding offices and advisory teams mention that they generally don't like to work out of the San Francisco office or with San Francisco-based due diligence folks.

headline: KPMG is a great place to work!
pros: KPMG offers an environment that allows an individual to grow and learn at an accelerated pace. In addition, the individuals that make up KPMG are driven and hardworking; while still able to make the workplace fun and exciting. KPMG is a great place to start a career in business even if your long term goals do not involve public accounting. The amount of information and technical experience you learn is unmatched. There is always someone willing to help you with a problem or teach you a new skill. I am proud to be a KPMG employee. KPMG is a great place to work!
cons: Working in public accounting requires longer work days during certian parts of the year, and anyone interested in working for any of the Big 4 firms should be aware of that. While at times the days can be long it is important to remember that they only occur during certain parts of the year, and the learning opportunities during that time are priceless.

Experts around the business to learn from and network with to really develop practical and soft-skill sets
cons: Lower pay compared to industry

headline: A great place to learn, but unattractive short term economics
pros:
1. Global brand, prestigious firm.
2. Great learning opportunity: a crash course in business understanding and technical accounting topics.
3. Great exposure to job opportunities outside of the firm.
4. Above average starting pay, and attractive earnings opportunity OVER TIME (a considerable amount of time actually).
5. Professional environment and people.
6. Contrary to popular opinion, work-life balance is respected. You will work long hours and travel at certain times, but this is to be expected in any professional career path.
cons:
1. Career trajectory: 12-15 year partner path? I struggle to think that it takes 15 years to gain the proper amount of leadership, sales and professional experience to be a partner. This is an incredibly long partner path compared to tier 1 consulting firms like McKinsey or Bain, or most law firms. Your most talented, but impatient, assets will leave before then (this shows in turnover data).
2. Compensation trajectory: starting pay is above average, however you have a pretty flat trajectory until you make partner. Real economic opportunity isn't available until you are a partner. Again, the most talented people won't wait that long.

headline: Overall I have had a very good experience while working for KPMG.  Lately is a different story.

cons: CSS group has limited opportunities for growth.  If you work in one of KPMG's smaller offices that will also limit your chances for growth within the Firm.  KPMG has recently put a hiring freeze on all CSS personnel (Ops Sevices, IT, Marketing, Admin Assist, Recruiting and HR) and has started moving some of these jobs to the Global Delivery Center i.e. India.

headline: Senior Associate Strategy
pros:
- Great people to work with in the Associate / Senior Associate levels

 - Opportunity to build platforms and frameworks from the ground up as the group is still relatively small in size
cons:
- Ridiculously long hours to the point where employees are burnt out. Majority of projects operate like that
 -Only 4 'hub' locations in the US (Chicago, NYC, Silicon Valley, Atlanta)
 - Compensation is well below McK / BCG / Bain. Poor bonus structure that is not based on merit
 - Limited opportunities for advancement
 - The company has hired a lot of Managers / Directors from different firms and is lacking a unified company culture. In addition, there are no checks and balances on team culture and a lot of projects have very poor team dynamics.

headline: End of the Road for IT
pros:

cons: Morale in IT is an all time low and the IT department is in a state of crisis. NOTHING is being done to retain talent. There is a serious need for good leadership. Too many people in "leadership" positions have no idea what the next 2-3 years will look like. All the effort and focus in on Outsourcing IT and there is no vision for the organization.

cons:
KPMG's consultancy practice is being rebuilt -after KPMG sold its consulting practice to Atos- and it seems sometimes management is re-inventing the wheel. the partnership model inhibits global integration and career opportunities making the company very country focused. 

You have to create opportunities, the company won't do it for you...

headline: KPMG - Dead end career - no work/life balance
pros: 25 days of vacation.  nice office.  nothing much to say.  The annual salary raise is well below inflation rate and, not too mention, the rental raise in New York City.
cons: KPMG has too much politics.  There is lack of learning opportunity.  Salary is not competitive.  The work is long hour.  The morale is low except for the new-comers.  The staff people are taken seriously about quality of work but totally lack of recognition.  The management does not have any respect.  they have very poor time management.  If they have problem, they will blame it down to the staff.  If they have credit, they take them all by themselves.  Staff people feel like working hard for nothing because all credits has been taken by management level.  People who gets promotion are people who play game with the management, but not the people who do the hard work.  Ethics is bad in office.  therefore KPMG has such a high employee turnover rate.  The annual salary raise is well below inflation rate and, not too mention, the rental raise in New York City.

headline: Stressful and miserable place to work
pros:
-Very demanding so learnt a lot
-Started off my career with a low benchmark for what a full-time job is like and gave me low expectations from a company. Henceforth this has made me really appreciate what working in a nice company is like and has made me more tolerant of negative aspects because this one was so brutal.
cons:
-Long and unappreciated working hours. Rarely thanked for your work and looked down on if you left within contractual working hours.
-Had a 1:1 performance review with my manager twice during the year I was there and both were largely critical and negative experiences.
-Everyone felt on edge and under extreme pressure all the time.
-Horrible, negative, toxic atmosphere.
-The team I was in was understaffed so about 6 of us had to do work for about twenty especially as people kept leaving.
-Constantly undermined by manager and honestly called stupid
-Incredibly low  wages despite the arduous work put in which is demonstrative of how ungrateful and unappreciated we were.
-Poor opportunities for career progression and the salary bonuses offered were pathetic.
-No focused training provided on the job. You had to learn as you went and were treated like an idiot if you made mistakes/asked too many questions.

- You get extremely specialized very quickly (Captive Insurance, Investment/Hedge Funds or offshore bank subsidiaries), which may limit working with other clients in different industries

headline: Not great for HR professionals - go elsewhere
pros: I worked with a great group of people and made many connections there. I was able to gain some skills and exposure to an HR/Recruiting environment. It was a good start to my career. The people who you get to work with for the most part are genuinely very nice people.
cons:
Very low pay compared to their competitors and other companies.
Hardly any opportunity for growth/learning. People stay in the same positions for years and go no where and have little to show for it.
They don't award high-performers adequately (at least not on the HR/non-client serving side).
The culture they've built wants you to constantly do more work and take on more responsibilities without compensating/recognizing you fairly for it.
It seems as though people are leaving in droves and morale is fairly low.

headline: Bullying Manager
pros:
Location
Flexibility to work from home
cons:
They do not seem to practice what they preach; they hire/promote highly inexperienced managers; that bully colleagues. It was an awful experience and I hope they get exposed to how badly they treat employees as many others have left with anxiety and depression due to poor management.

If you speak out and ask for it to stop; you will not have a job.

Manager gave me pointless tasks that had nothing to do with my job.

Manager made me feel less important and undervalued.

Deliberately called me out on my second day for being 1 minute late.

Manager grabbed me on my shoulder a few times, in an aggressive manner.

The worst thing that happened was that I was excluded from working with people in my team for the entire time I was there. Manager stopped me from working with people and taking part in activities that was related to my work.

headline: Good firm, great people. Mediocre communication from management.
pros: As a Big 4 accounting firm, KPMG has many global Fortune 500 in its client base. It is know for its strength/expertise in commercial banking, but has large clients in all industries (e.g. General Electric, Pfizer.) The firm affords the opportunity to travel, if so desired, and I really enjoy the people I work with. Everyone seems genuine, intelligent and hard-working. The firm seems genuinely behind the work/life initiative it has been promoting for a number of years and generally seems to accommodate an employee's desire to transfer to another office, work an abbreviated schedule (to spend time with family) or go on an international rotation.
cons: As a firm heavily involved in the financial services industry, we are feeling the effects of the downturn in the economy, specifically as it relates to the banking and finance industries. There have been 2 rounds of layoffs this year (March & May), neither of which were communicated to the staff. Additionally, although the firm recently announced earning are not down substantially, the general gossip is that raises and bonus will be off substantially from last year. We are all aware of what’s going on with the economy, but would appreciate an update to the firm’s results (vis-à-vis compensation), so changes don’t appear as an 11th hour event.

headline: KPMG Hard but Rewarding
pros: KPMG is a true meritocracy. You are generally judged on the work that you do. There is little politics. KPMG provides employees with the opportunity to grow that is rare. Exposure to clients provides exceptional experience. You work with extremely talented and dedicated professionals. You receive the view into your clients business that is rare. You will see a picture that only executives of the company do. You get to look at their business at a high level and get down into the details as well.
cons: Hours are, of course, really bad. If you get the on a bad client if may be difficult to get off of the client without be regarded as complainer. Your immediate supervisor has significant say over your performance evaluation; if you have supervisor who is not in your corner you may not be given a fair evaluation. It is very hierarchical, by necessity, but it has it downfalls.

headline: Don't recommend

A certain prestige / recognition in the market

headline: Great place to start a Career, but...
pros: KPMG is a great company to have on your resume. The name of the company itself is enough credibility to assure for many future opportunities to come. The company is great in terms of many factors; Benefits, Time-off (Personal, Vacation), Flex Time etc. Great work life balance, I can't recall a time where I stayed for over-time, but that's also because my department was not client facing. People generally are professional, friendly, and easy to get along with.
cons: The pay is much lower compared to what is being on the marketplace. Promotions are extremely rigid and take a very, VERY long time. There is a HR policy which many will not be aware of until hired into the company. There are job levels which you need to follow consecutively (i.e.. if you are a level 5, there is no moving to level 7, only to level 6). Unfortunately some departments will have one level but not the next (ie. you are a level 5, there is no level 6 but there is a level 7), which in affect restricts promotions until you transfer out of your department or a new position is created (don't count on that). So much for being a company which fosters career growth...

headline: Average
pros: Intense commitment to training and development opportunities. Access to top tier clients with a moderate level of strategic projects. Great senior associate retention bonus. Smart and driven peers.
cons: Increasingly transactional and implementation driven projects. Many of directors and partners were strong individual contributors but have little understanding of effective management. Travel for the sake of travel as opposed to needs-driven. Work-life balance and flexibility is touted as a major focus point, but not yet practiced at the top.

headline: A great place to work

cons: Lower salary than many like for like competitors, but job is less of a factory!

headline: Brief view point from graduate
pros: Culture and people. KPMG is just like what you expect from a Big 4. Training and experience, to work for KPMG is to take the first step into the financial world.
cons: The greatest concern for most graduates is the starting salary. Sadly, this is an area KPMG is not as competitive in relative to each compititors. They advertise on their website that their remuneration is competitive to the rest of the market, but truth be told it is more on the lower end of the scale. But they do try to compensate with other benefits. But it is difficult to evaluate the value of these other additional benefits like sick leave and such.

headline: Pros and cons of working for KPMG
pros: The main reason to work for KPMG is the career advancement opportunities available after you've worked at the firm for at least 2 years. I've found that having the 2+ years experience on your resume almost guarantees you will be hired into a higher salaried position than if you don't have it. It is faster to work yourself up at the firm than work your way up in industry. If you stay focused on that, it is worth putting in your time with the firm.
cons: The biggest downside is the demanding pressures of constantly trying to balance work and life. This is especially difficult if you are married and/or have kids. Although the firm preaches work/life "balance", this really is not the case. You can only focus 100% on one or the other. You can only be an EP at work or home--you choose. Usually, you justify working those insane long hours and missing school events by believing that all this sacrafice is for your family's future. In reality, there is no work/life balance at KPMG.

headline: Senior Associate Strategy

- Great people to work with in the Associate / Senior Associate levels

cons:
- Ridiculously long hours to the point where employees are burnt out. Majority of projects operate like that
 -Only 4 'hub' locations in the US (Chicago, NYC, Silicon Valley, Atlanta)
 - Compensation is well below McK / BCG / Bain. Poor bonus structure that is not based on merit
 - Limited opportunities for advancement
 - The company has hired a lot of Managers / Directors from different firms and is lacking a unified company culture. In addition, there are no checks and balances on team culture and a lot of projects have very poor team dynamics.

headline: Great exposure, poor management and staff benefit
pros: This is really a good place for accounting grad to start a career be it professional development or salary. You get exposed to the intricacies of financial accounting and be the forefront in adopting the latest IFRS.
cons:
Senior management not transparent on their management decision. 

Case 1:
Has worked with one Senior Manager for one big engagement and yet he is totally slacking off. He did not visit the client premises for the whole 3 month audit. Submitted files for him to review and he will gladly click "Reviewed" yet knows nothing about the company. Incompetent to the extent that he has no principles at all, subservient to client demand eventhough partner disagrees. So it's left to the senior to clean up the mess. Wonder how even get to be a Senior Manager

Case 2:
Extremely demanding and petty manager.  A technical sound manager which holds everybody to his high expectation. Yet he himself is slow in producing workpapers and can only blame the team for everything.
