cons: You have to be in the right team and work with the right people.  Otherwise, you can be miserable (but, this is the case with any job!).  Client facing jobs are always unpredictable and demanding, so work-life-balance can be a challenge sometimes.

headline: Great place to start a career, not great at keeping people.
pros:
- Great place to start a career
- Good technical training 
- Great place to network
- Good boost on resumes
- People are generally friendly when they are not stressed out (but often they are stressed) 
- Everyone is hard working
- Promotion and salary are predictable
cons:
- Other than entry levels and partners, people are not happy here
- People are patient with entry levels. Once you been here long enough, the patience runs low
- Work life balance is a joke. People work overtime without pay. Management expects you to be on call 7 days a week. 
- They overwork high performing employees, causing them to leave
- Mangers doesn't know how to manage people and projects
- Top management is trying to make the workplace better, but often falls short. 
- Due to heavy workload, training on the job is limited.

headline: Employer for life
pros: First and foremost the people. I've been employed at companies where the work was less than ideal but the people I worked with were stellar, which made the day get on well. Fortunately, at KPMG you have the best of all worlds. Great people, great professionals, great professional, personal, and social development opportunities. Truly cannot say enough about it.
cons: Every place of employment has "cons", however, so far I've not found any glaring issues. I was pleased with their benefits, my salary, and my leadership.

headline: Project Coordinator
pros: good culture and great people. Very happy
cons: so far so good. No cons yet

headline: Senior Associate
pros:
Experience working with big clients 
Supportive Colleagues
cons:
Work life balance
Travel to remote locations

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Great training, skill development, and mentorship
cons: Compensation is not competitive, time off difficult to take

headline: Fantastic growth
pros:
1. Fantastic growth 
2. A company which cares about people 
3. If you perform well, you will be compensated both monetarily and career wise 
4. You’ll get all the support you require. All you need to do is - ask for it
cons:
1. You need a certain X factor to survive and be successful. There’s a certain lively, buzzing work culture that is in the fabric of the company. If you are Mr/Ms outside hire you will struggle to adapt.
2. It’s easy to get lost on one long project and not learn anything in 2 years. Make sure you speak to people from your department/ service line. Especially those who you don’t work with

headline: Too much work politics for promotions
pros:
Good location
Good office
Some great people
cons:
Lack of support for immigrants
Miserly with visa costs
Too much politics for promotions

headline: Met great people but incompatible as an employer
pros:
-a well recognized brand good for new graduates
-a global company so there are opportunities for work abroad if you strive hard for it
cons: There was no training in my department, or much training for any department besides audit. You are told that you will "learn on the job".  However, the reality is that the other staff are also unsure of how to assign tasks to you. Interns are usually not briefed on the project or the company background beforehand. This creates confusion and inefficiency on the job.

headline: Great
pros: Great place to work, come here
cons: There are no cons at working here

headline: Associste
pros: Good experience and training especially to start a career.
cons: Stagnant pay, little to no bonuses, layoffs, poor culture when it comes to employee appreciation and retention.

headline: Great career but experience depends a lot on the team you join
pros: Exciting projects and great exposure. Good place to learn.
cons: Poor management culture, low work-life balance, and lower than industry pay for levels below manager

headline: Awesome!
pros: So helpful, was able to easily transfer
cons: Long hours and work-life balance could be difficult

headline: Great culture
pros: Company culture is great, everyone is true to the company values and the people you work with are very intelligent and supportive. There is a strong culture of personal development with goal setting and feedback.
cons: Can be difficult to move into new areas or try out new things. This is especially the case for E grades (new joiners 1 - 3 years) with little reward structure or kudos for asking to take on more responsibility.

headline: It is good for maximum 2-3 years.
pros: Good reputation of the company.
cons: Opportunities for promotion and financial benefits seem to decrease.

headline: Broken Business Model
pros:
- Experience is sought after and valued in the industry
- High performance culture
cons:
- Higher than expected attrition rates cause undue stress for remaining employees
- Lack of initiative to adjust in a rapidly changing industry
- No incentives for best employees (monetary or otherwise)
- Very impersonal: refers to employees as "resources" or "bodies"

headline: Friendly Company
pros:
- Working with top managers
-
cons:
- Less time for yourself
- Mostly out of office

headline: Good place for college grads, but be careful..
pros: Excellent training material, vast intranet resources, lot of small perks given out, fairly enjoyable experience outside of the work place with co-workers.
cons: Long hours, miscommunication from management and lack of follow-through.  A little gossipy in a cut-throat clic type way.
